title: How To Make Your Bathroom Smell Good
excerpt: A while ago I walked into my husband‚Äôs bathroom and I just wasn‚Äôt loving the smell. Not that there was anything bad or gross in there, but it just needed to be smelling more like a spa. Am I right?
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
A while ago I walked into my husband‚Äôs bathroom and I just wasn‚Äôt loving the smell. Not that there was anything bad or gross in there, but it just needed to be smelling more like a spa. Am I right?

So in this post I want to share with you how I whipped that whole situation into shape and how easy it was. Now, it‚Äôs smelling like the Mandarin Oriental and is totally dialed in, no matter what goes on in there.

The thing is, I want to love every detail of my house. My life and work is so chatoic that when I‚Äôm at home I want to feel relaxed and zen and peaceful. So every.little.thing. matters. Right down to the bathmat.

How To Make Your Bathroom Smell Good

Let‚Äôs set up the foundation of the whole house first, and then let it carry over to the bathroom. You do this by making the best homemade potpourri. My stepmom taught me this and all you do is take a small pot, fill it with water, orange slices and cinnamon sticks and let it simmer.

It‚Äôs easy, non-toxic and sets the best vibe throughout your whole house. A little better for winter/cozy weather but works all year around, really.

We can‚Äôt forget about the actual toilet. Poo~Pourri should be in every single bathroom in the world.

You basically just spritz it into the toilet bowl before-you-go. The spray is a pure blend of NATURAL ESSENTIAL OILS that creates a film on the surface of the water.

The protective barrier traps the bad odors under the surface, before it ever begins! I MEAN!!! All you‚Äôll smell is a refreshing bouquet of natural essential oils. I love preventative measure.

This is my favorite brand of cleaning products (use code SKINNY for 15% off) because they‚Äôre all natural and you need to make sure your bathroom is clean to make it smell good.

The brand is family-owned and all their products are non-toxic. The family‚Äôs entire health journey really interesting actually. They are living proof that switching to a clean, chemical-free lifestyle can do wonders for your health. Be sure to check out their products.

Because always candles. However I think a lot of us know now that certain wicks from candles are full of nasty stuff, even if they say non-toxic. That‚Äôs why we made The Skinny Confidential candle with a 100% cotton wick, pure soy wax and eucalyptus essential oil. It isn‚Äôt just a candle, it‚Äôs a better choice. You can learn more here.

Other Ideas:

+ keep your bathroom clean.

+ clean out drains with white vinegar and baking soda.

+ if possible, use a fan or open a window when showering to keep away musty smells, mold and mildew or get a Jaspr.

+ try a eucalyptus shower to make your bathroom smell like a spa.

+ change your towels often.

+ get yourself the best bathmat in the world to keep things clean and looking chic.

Swap out old shower curtains often. Fabric and plastic curtains can trap moisture and cause unpleasant odors. A fresh curtain instantly makes the space smell nice and look chic.

Upgrade your toilet paper storage. Keep rolls in a lidded basket with a sachet of lavender or eucalyptus tucked inside. Every time you reach for a roll, the air will smell fresh.

Eliminate bad smells before they start. Wipe down walls and tiles weekly with a vinegar-water solution. Bathrooms hold on to hidden buildup that creates bad smells over time.

Add greenery. Plants like peace lilies and ferns naturally filter air and make your bathroom smell fresh while giving it that calming, home spa vibe.

Rotate scents seasonally. Think mint or citrus for summer, and cedar or vanilla for winter. Switching it up keeps your bathroom feeling like a new, luxurious spa each season.

What are you tips for a nice, clean smelling bathroom? Let me know below.

x, Lauryn

title: Step Inside Bond‚Äôs Nursery

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
You may have seen peaks of Bond‚Äôs nursery on Instagram, or already seen The Chalkboard article that went up the other day. Either way I‚Äôm so excited to give you the full tour of Bond‚Äôs nursery.

We decided to work with David Ko of Maison Ko and we‚Äôre so thrilled with the results, I can‚Äôt even put it into words. It‚Äôs perfect.

David was such a pleasure to work with. He totally executed my vision and understood that although it‚Äôs a nursery, it‚Äôs also a room that Bond can grow into. Overall the vibe was texture, depth, neutral but rich color with interesting touches to make the room unique.

You can shop the whole nursery look here and in the meantime, read on to learn about the whole process and the details that brought the vision together.

Step Inside Bond‚Äôs Nursery

What was the first piece or idea that kicked off the whole vision for the nursery?

DK: The idea that really laid the groundwork for Bond‚Äôs nursery was doing some sort of mural wall treatment. At first, we were looking into hiring an artist to do a custom hand-painted mural, but then we came across this wallpaper and knew it was the one. We wanted it to feel moody, yet still a touch whimsical‚Äîsomething that Bond could grow into and not feel permanently newborn. The colors in the wallpaper really inspired the rest of the room and led the overall direction.

LB: The vision of baby Bond‚Äôs nursery was to incorporate texture, artistic wallpaper, but without feeling too thematic. The room had to have depth with calming and soothing energy for the baby. Simply stepping into the room is an experience, and along with functional, unique details, meditation chimes, and red lights, David worked with me to execute our vision perfectly.¬†

We focused on texture and richness with deep shades of evergreen and chocolate brown. I didn‚Äôt want it to feel beige and muted‚Äîopposite, actually. I also wanted the nursery to tell a story, so many elements are personalized: from specific books, to Michael‚Äôs silver baby rattle, to pictures and details.

Bringing in the baby element was obviously important, but I challenged David and his team to do something you don‚Äôt see on Instagram all the time. For example, the darker crib (lighter version here) feels masculine, yet there‚Äôs still a baby-esque aura.

Also, I am huge on organization‚Äîeach drawer, closet area, and shelf is efficiently organized with thought and purpose so that when the baby arrived, everything was streamlined.

What did you want this nursery to feel like‚Äîfor you, for the baby, and for your family?

DK: When we started working together, all Lauryn told me was that she didn‚Äôt want it to feel like a typical beige nursery. She wanted it to feel elevated yet approachable, suited for a newborn, but not overly trendy or something you‚Äôve seen a thousand times. Lauryn wanted it to be a space that felt unique and truly special for Bond.

LB: Along with our home being a place where we can all recharge, each child is unique and deserves their own space that reflects their essence. My daughter‚Äôs room is sort of a pinkish-lilac and white, and my son‚Äôs room is very much a rock ‚Äòn roll vibe. The new baby also needs his own moment and David and his team really helped us to achieve Bond‚Äôs essence.

It brings me joy to create spaces for children to relax their nervous system. My Mom did it for me by sewing curtains and duvet covers and making my room specifically tailored to me. I remember loving to be in my room and feeling comforted in my bedroom. So creating that for my own kids is a priority. It‚Äôs funny, my Dad walked into the baby‚Äôs nursery the other day and said, ‚ÄúYour Mom was just like this with you and your sister, Faye.‚Äù

title: 6 Fall Skin Care Tips You Can Start Now
excerpt: If there‚Äôs one thing we‚Äôll allow ourselves to be a basic over, it‚Äôs fall. How can you not? Between the gorgeous fall scents to the upcoming time with your family it‚Äôs maybe the best season of the year.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
If there‚Äôs one thing we‚Äôll allow ourselves to be a basic over, it‚Äôs fall. How can you not? Between the gorgeous fall scents to the upcoming time with your family it‚Äôs maybe the best season of the year.

And fall fashion? We‚Äôre here for it.
One thing we‚Äôre NOT so pumped for though, is seasonal skin changes.
It‚Äôs that time of year when the air outside gets cooler and drier, and our skincare routines need some modification to keep up with the environment. Because drier air = drier, duller skin.¬†

So how best to keep your skin bouncy and beautiful year-round?
As always, we‚Äôve looked into it for you. We‚Äôve got all the info you need to keep your skin glowing and healthy all year long.

6 Cr√©me de la Cr√©me Fall Skin Care Tips

To get the most out of your fall skincare routine, you‚Äôve got to know how the changes in weather actually affect your skin. You don‚Äôt want to overdo it, after all‚Äîif you‚Äôre moving all the way from light skincare to slugging, but your face is only slightly more dry than in the summer, you might end up with a completely different problem. That‚Äôs not the move.

Everyone‚Äôs skin is different, and many of us are dealing with different types of weather changes. So, before we get into what to do about your seasonal skin change, let‚Äôs talk about what that change actually looks like for you.

How Does Cold Weather Affect Skin?

The biggest thing affecting your skin as the seasons change is the humidity. As the weather gets cooler, humidity levels tend to drop as well.

While this can be amazing for those of us whose hair tends to change styles in the humidity, it can also dry out our skin, leaving our summer skincare struggling to keep up. Dry, cold air can also make fine lines and wrinkles more noticeable.

But, it‚Äôs not just the air outside that‚Äôs stealing all your hydration‚Äîit‚Äôs the air inside, too. When you turn on the heat or kindle an indoor fire, the indoor moisture is sucked out of the air as well. So even when you get inside, your skin may still be suffering.

Don‚Äôt sweat it. We‚Äôve got the ideas you need to stay hydrated and baby soft this fall and winter.

Here‚Äôs Exactly How To Take Care Of Your Skin In The Fall

The first thing you can do to combat the dry air for your skin is to LITERALLY combat the dry air. Put some humidity back into your life. Your skin will thank you.

Lauryn‚Äôs so obsessed with this humidifier, she actually designed her own. It was limited edition but you can still get the bedside humidifier AND a TSC aroma diffuser from the Canopy, and they really work.

As the air gets drier both inside and out, we need to boost our skincare products to add and lock in moisture.

Let‚Äôs start at the beginning: You‚Äôll need a fragrance-free cleanser, like this one Lauryn loves, that gently removes makeup and environmental residue from your face.¬†

It‚Äôs a good idea to get fragrance-free body wash as well. Even if your skin type isn‚Äôt sensitive, you‚Äôll have more sensitive skin in the fall/winter. Fragrances and sensitive skin do NOT get along.

After cleansing, follow your normal skin care routine, but consider swapping out your products for more hydrating versions. You‚Äôll want to look for products with humectants like hyaluronic acid and glycerin. This Water Drench Hyaluronic Cloud Cream has both.

Reducing the frequency of treatments that dry your skin can help prevent weather-related irritation, as well as swapping light lotions for heavier creams.

As ALWAYS, you‚Äôll need to protect your skin from sun damage by using a product with at least SPF 30.
HOT TIP: The best sunscreen on the block is the Caffeinated Sunscreen from TSC. It‚Äôs SPF 40, caffeinated, and super nourishing.

For a super moisturizing skin care routine, check out Lauryn‚Äôs Korean skincare routine or her go-to routine that she always updates.

title: This Caribbean Island Ranked The Cheapest Fall Getaway For Americans
excerpt: With travel costs on the rise, the dream of a budget-friendly fall getaway can feel like it's slipping away. The desire for white-sand beaches and turquoise water is real, but so is the hit to your wallet. So, where can American travelers find that perfect Caribbean escape wit‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
With travel costs on the rise, the dream of a budget-friendly fall getaway can feel like it's slipping away. The desire for white-sand beaches and turquoise water is real, but so is the hit to your wallet. So, where can American travelers find that perfect Caribbean escape without breaking the bank?

The results are in, and a clear winner has emerged. Here at Travel Off Path, we‚Äôve been analyzing the latest travel data, and one island nation is consistently delivering incredible value, officially making it the cheapest and smartest choice for a fall beach trip this year.

That destination is the Dominican Republic.

‚úàÔ∏è Why The Flights Are So Cheap

Getting to paradise is half the battle, and this is where the Dominican Republic has a massive advantage. The sheer volume of flights from the U.S. means fierce competition, and that competition drives prices way down. Budget carriers like Spirit and Frontier have a huge presence here, forcing major airlines to compete on price.

The result? You can find incredible deals. We‚Äôre seeing nonstop, roundtrip flights to Punta Cana (PUJ) this fall from hubs like Fort Lauderdale (FLL) and Orlando (MCO) for as low as $250. Even from major northern cities like New York (JFK) and Newark (EWR), deals can often be found for under $400. It‚Äôs one of the most accessible and affordable Caribbean islands to fly to from the U.S.

üè® The All-Inclusive Is King

This is the Dominican Republic‚Äôs superpower. The island is the undisputed king of the affordable all-inclusive resort. Because there are so many amazing properties competing for your business, you can find luxury experiences for a fraction of what you‚Äôd pay on other islands.

Fall is the shoulder season‚Äîthe sweet spot between the summer rush and the peak winter crowds‚Äîwhich means the deals get even better. You can regularly find 4-star, all-inclusive resorts right on the stunning beaches of Punta Cana for under $150 a night. That means your room, all your meals, all your drinks, and your entertainment are covered. It‚Äôs a level of value that is almost impossible to beat anywhere else in the Caribbean.

üå¥ Free & Affordable Fun

One of the best things to do in the Dominican Republic doesn‚Äôt cost a penny: relaxing on its world-class beaches. Punta Cana is lined with miles of pristine, public-access white sand beaches where you can soak up the sun for free.

But it‚Äôs not just about the beach. For a dose of culture, you can take an affordable bus trip to the capital, Santo Domingo, and explore the historic

, a UNESCO World Heritage site. Wander the cobblestone streets, see the first cathedral of the Americas, and enjoy a delicious, authentic Dominican lunch at a local spot for under $10.

Zona Colonial

‚òÄÔ∏è The Perfect Fall Weather

If you‚Äôre chasing that endless summer feeling, the Dominican Republic delivers. By October and November, the main rainy season is over, and the hurricane risk drops significantly. You‚Äôre left with idyllic weather: sunny skies, daytime temperatures in the mid-80s, and warm, turquoise water that‚Äôs perfect for swimming. It‚Äôs the ideal time to visit before the high-season crowds (and prices) arrive for the holidays.

title: Arew√† Basit on Her Amy Sherald Portrait and Alchemizing Trans Joy
excerpt: In the international queer community, Arew√† Basit is known as a dancing, singing don-diva who makes music, performs in drag, and co-leads the Black queer production organization Legacy . These days, she‚Äôs also making headlines for being the subject of a ‚Äúcontroversial‚Äù artwork‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
In the international queer community, Arew√† Basit is known as a dancing, singing don-diva who makes music, performs in drag, and co-leads the Black queer production organization Legacy. These days, she‚Äôs also making headlines for being the subject of a ‚Äúcontroversial‚Äù artwork by Amy Sherald. The controversy in question: a painting depicting her as the Statue of Liberty in a pink bob. In July, Sherald pulled her exhibition American Sublime from the National Portrait Gallery (NPG) in Washington, DC, over concerns that the institution would censor her painting of Arew√†. Amid the nation‚Äôs descent into fascism, ‚ÄúTrans Forming Liberty‚Äù (2024) calls into question whether institutions represent the state or the people ‚Äî and whether they‚Äôll ever learn from their past.

The Dallas-born musician, performer, and artist is no stranger to adversity. In an interview with Hyperallergic, Arew√† explained that teachers often labeled her as unruly and disruptive for her ‚Äúlarger-than-life personality‚Äù and ‚Äúambition to entertain and to express.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeing a queer kid in Texas, I was often reprimanded for just existing,‚Äù Arew√† recalled. ‚ÄúI was disciplined for being too effeminate, for getting attention that my family or people thought was unwarranted.‚Äù

That same repressive impulse may have influenced the NPG to allegedly consider excluding Sherald‚Äôs portrait of Arew√† from the show. (A representative for the Smithsonian Institution previously told Hyperallergic

that it ‚Äúcould not come to an agreement with the artist.‚Äù) Days after Sherald withdrew her exhibition, ‚ÄúTrans Forming Liberty‚Äù graced the cover of the

; on August 21, the White House included the painting on a

hit listtargeting 26 artworks and shows depicting queer, trans, and migrant experiences as tools of so-called ‚Äúdivisive narratives.‚Äù

Hyperallergic)

Arew√† recognized that the virality of this story speaks volumes about the blatant attacks on trans people across the country and the ways they are often sensationalized in the media and that ‚Äúthe narrative of being visible as a Black, queer trans individual has never been more complex.‚Äù

‚ÄúAmerica likes to tell Black people what kind of a Black person they think they should be,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI think this country was gonna have an issue with a Black trans person being in the same museum as all of the presidents.‚Äù

Arew√† first gained mainstream recognition in 2019 after joining the first all-queer cast of the dating show Are You the One?. Though she balked at the performative aspects of reality TV, she knew her presence would make an impact on young trans people who don‚Äôt get to see themselves on screen ‚Äî particularly in a media ecosystem that chews up Black trans femmes, capitalizes on them, and spits them out. She sings about this experience on her EP Archive, which drops on November 11, drawing from a performance she gave on Fire Island, a queer getaway known for being overwhelmingly White and cis. Like many of her trans sisters, she felt loved and embraced during the day and discarded by night.

‚ÄúThe people who told me I was special were most often Black people,‚Äù Arew√† said, reflecting on the role models who shaped her upbringing. ‚ÄúAnd so I learned from an early age that the only thing that was gonna protect what makes me special is to embrace it.‚Äù

Arew√† drew a comparison between the scrutiny of her portrait and historical reactions to other muses and models, namely the socialite Virginie Am√©lie Avegno Gautreau in John Singer Sargent‚Äôs infamous ‚ÄúMadame X‚Äù (1884), which scandalized the public and art critics upon its debut at the Paris Salon.

The painting, Arew√† explained, was the original reference for ‚ÄúTrans Forming Liberty,‚Äù which she was chosen to model for after Sherald put out a casting call for a Black drag artist. ‚ÄúWhat she found was a video of me performing ‚ÄòI Can‚Äôt Stand the Rain‚Äô by Ann Peebles,‚Äù Arew√† commented.

title: Kimsooja Offers Refuge in an Anti-Refugee World
excerpt: AMSTERDAM ‚Äî Whenever I encounter artworks or architecture from the so-called ‚ÄúDutch Golden Age,‚Äù perhaps more accurately known as its colonial period ‚Äî a daily occurrence since my relocation to the Netherlands last year ‚Äî I‚Äôm reminded of Teju Cole‚Äôs reevaluation of Vermeer‚Äôs p‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
AMSTERDAM ‚Äî¬†Whenever I encounter artworks or architecture from the so-called ‚ÄúDutch Golden Age,‚Äù perhaps more accurately known as its colonial period ‚Äî a daily occurrence since my relocation to the Netherlands last year ‚Äî I‚Äôm reminded of Teju Cole‚Äôs reevaluation of Vermeer‚Äôs paintings as ‚Äúan artifact inescapably involved in the world‚Äôs messiness.‚Äù Cole argues that the nation‚Äôs history of violent extraction and global oppression during that era, notably its instrumental role in the slave trade, suffuses Vermeer‚Äôs seemingly innocent scenes of a milkmaid or a woman in a pearl necklace. Works that use ultramarine paint made from lapis lazuli, or portraits depicting something as benign as silvery cutlery, abstract the vicious methods that produce such wares. The paint was likely sourced from a 17th-century Afghan mine, while the precious metal probably came from the brutal Potos√≠ silver excavation in Bolivia ‚Äî both items available due to the Dutch East and West India Company‚Äôs key role in capitalist exploitation. That‚Äôs to say nothing about the country‚Äôs active involvement in the transatlantic slave trade, trafficking 1.6 million enslaved people over two centuries and abetting the largest forced migration in history.¬†

These facts came to mind when I encountered Kimsooja‚Äôs delicate bottari, or traditional Korean textile bundles of cherished objects carried during travel, dotting the floor of the Oude Kerk (Old Church), Amsterdam‚Äôs oldest building-turned-contemporary art institution, as the city celebrates its 750th anniversary. Built 300 years before the Dutch colonial period, the church expanded into its current iteration in 1570, 30 years before the Dutch East India Company prepared to embark on a campaign that would establish Amsterdam as an economic powerhouse through proto-capitalist means. ‚ÄúThe church could exist, flourish, and expand partly thanks to the proceeds of the major trading companies in the Golden Age,‚Äù reads the church‚Äôs About Us page on their website, adding that some names and coats of arms ‚Äúimmortalized‚Äù in the building were part of that exploitation. Though it does not explicitly state this intention in exhibition materials, with its injection of Kimsooja‚Äôs quietly disruptive bottari, a form central to her four-decade practice, To Breathe ‚Äî Mokum, accidentally or not, illuminates Dutch colonial history and skewers contemporary right-wing attitudes around diversity and migration that resist multiculturalism in favor of a dominant cultural or national identity. The name of the exhibition derives from the Yiddish word

mokum, meaning ‚Äúcity‚Äù or ‚Äúsafe haven,‚Äù contradicting the

recently dissolved Dutch government, whose anti-immigration party attempted to freeze asylum applications and limit family reunification, among other far-right measures.

Bottari only partially make up the site-specific exhibition. Each bundle is filled with donated clothing from Amsterdam‚Äôs various cultural communities, while the wrapping cloths themselves range from West African wax prints to not-as-easily-identifiable linens. Diffraction grating film serves as the exhibition‚Äôs other chief element. Pasted over 44,000 of the church‚Äôs imposing window panes, the iridescent film refracts ever-shifting sunlight into a shattering pool of color. Multicolor light swaddles the delicate bottari, wresting attention away from the church‚Äôs monumental, gilded organ or ancient stone graves that tile the floor, toward sacks filled with migration histories, reveling in the glory of diversity inextricably woven into and held within a discrete, formalized object. Look up to take in the grand architecture, and you might trip on a bottari or find yourself distracted by a rainbow ‚Äî a visceral reminder that this seemingly beautiful paean to the Dutch national project might be more subversive than its exhibition materials suggest. Like Vermeer‚Äôs milkmaids, these bottari are inextricable from their contemporary world, one in which increasingly nativist governments seek to sanitize the past and censor the present.

title: Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Send Shockwaves Through the Art World
excerpt: Thomas Fuchs had finished packing up several paintings from his Stuttgart-based gallery that he was preparing to exhibit at the Armory Show in New York last week when his shipping agent warned him about an unanticipated problem.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Thomas Fuchs had finished packing up several paintings from his Stuttgart-based gallery that he was preparing to exhibit at the Armory Show in New York last week when his shipping agent warned him about an unanticipated problem.

The art would not be subject to American customs duties, the agent told him, but he would have to declare each tool included in their shipment and pay a pricey fee on them because President Trump had ended the ‚Äúde minimis‚Äù provision covering less expensive items.¬†

Fuchs immediately pulled his power tools out of the shipping crate, flew to New York, and bought $200 worth of drills, screwdrivers, and nails at a Manhattan hardware store that he used to install the gallery‚Äôs booth before the fair‚Äôs Wednesday opening.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame,‚Äù Fuchs told Hyperallergic, noting that he wouldn‚Äôt be able to bring the items back to Germany. ‚ÄúThe tools I can handle, the important thing is that the art is tax-free. It would be a catastrophe otherwise.‚Äù

The sweeping array of emergency tariffs that Trump imposed on foreign trade in April has injected a new level of uncertainty during one of the art world‚Äôs busiest sale seasons.¬†

Artworks have largely been exempt from the new duties because they are generally categorized as cultural and informational materials, along with photographs, posters, publications, and other media, in the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.¬†

But several international galleries at last week‚Äôs fairs faced unanticipated costs from reciprocal levies depending on the type of object they shipped and what method they used to send them, not to mention jittery American buyers reluctant to fork over additional fees.¬†

Hyperallergic)

Southern Guild, a Cape Town-based gallery featuring African contemporary artists, paid a 30% duty on a unique designer table and a 10% levy on a ceramic vessel, while other works in the booth escaped without a tithe. Southern Guild founder Trevyn McGowan held shipping and tax meetings with her staff for one hour per day and still received a customs bill that was $20,000 higher than she had expected.

‚ÄúThis country is psychotic,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHow can you do this to collectors? We‚Äôre trying to develop this fantastic exchange between cultures and hemispheres and bring American artists to Africa and bring African artists to the West.‚Äù

Other galleries also absorbed new taxes on furniture, ceramics, and pieces less easily characterized as artworks than paintings and prints. SMAC Gallery, another Cape Town art space, had to pay a 15% fee on a small wooden table and two matching chairs they specifically had made for their exhibition booth.

‚ÄúPeople said, ‚ÄòWhy didn‚Äôt you just declare something else?‚Äô but we didn‚Äôt want to take any chances of it being held up in customs, and the fines are astronomical,‚Äù said Jean Butler, SMAC‚Äôs managing director.

Some European galleries that did not have to pay duties still needed to reassure buyers that their purchases would not come with hidden charges. Astrid Engstr√∂m, business director for the London and Baku-based Gazelli Art House, believed that widespread anxiety over tariff policy has dampened sales this year.

‚ÄúBuyers think that there are tariffs, and we were struggling to sell to US clients, but once we were here at the fair with the imported works, that worry was off the table,‚Äù Engstr√∂m told Hyperallergic.¬†

Even United States galleries have not escaped Trump‚Äôs trade wars. Yancey Richardson had to put a major sale at her Chelsea photography gallery on hold this year because a Canadian museum was afraid its government would impose a 25% duty on the purchase. Unlike the US, Canadian tariffs apply to both artworks and photographs.

Hyperallergic)

But artworks that faced the most scrutiny from customs officers were imported from China. Gallery reps with Tang Contemporary Art, which has eight outposts across East Asia and had a large booth at the Armory Show with several paintings, ceramic sculptures, and Ai Weiwei photographs, expected to encounter tariffs on Chinese works sold at the fair, but did not know what the customs rate would be.

title: LA‚Äôs Holocaust Museum Walks Back ‚ÄúNever Again‚Äù Statement, Sparking Outcry
excerpt: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Last Thursday, September 4, the Holocaust Museum LA posted a message on Instagram that was widely interpreted as a denunciation of Israel‚Äôs ongoing genocide in Gaza, which has been characterized as such by human rights organizations around the world. The first sl‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Last Thursday, September 4, the Holocaust Museum LA posted a message on Instagram that was widely interpreted as a denunciation of Israel‚Äôs ongoing genocide in Gaza, which has been characterized as such by human rights organizations around the world. The first slide featured a drawing of a hexagon formed by six linked arms ‚Äî various shades of brown and tan, the lightest one bearing a holocaust prisoner number tattoo ‚Äî with the words ‚Äú‚ÄòNever Again‚Äô Can‚Äôt Only Mean Never Again For Jews.‚Äù¬†

Two days later, the museum deleted the post and published an apology. Unlike the first Instagram post, for this one, the museum blocked commenters from weighing in.¬†

The Holocaust Museum LA, founded in 1961 by Holocaust survivors, is the oldest museum of its kind in the country. Its ‚ÄúNever Again‚Äù post ‚Äî the first such statement from the institution ‚Äî garnered more than 2,700 likes and 3,300 comments. The text continued on four slides: ‚ÄúJews Must Not Let the Trauma of our Past Silence our Conscience. Standing with Humanity does Not Betray Our People. It Honors Them. To Be Jewish is to Remember And to Act.‚Äù

Hyperallergicvia Instagram)

Although the post didn‚Äôt mention Gaza, Israel, or Palestine, most commenters understood it as a rebuke of Israel‚Äôs military assault on Gaza, which has killed more than 64,000 Palestinians. Reactions were mixed, with some commenters expressing appreciation for the museum‚Äôs recognition of ‚Äúour shared humanity.‚Äù Others decried the post as ‚Äúantisemitic‚Äù for drawing parallels between the Holocaust and the devastating, systematic slaughter of civilians in Gaza.

‚ÄúThis post is beyond disgraceful,‚Äù wrote one commenter. ‚ÄúWhoever created, approved, and posted this should be ashamed of themselves. Our ancestors are rolling in their graves.‚Äù

In response to such perspectives, another commenter observed, ‚ÄúIf a post encouraging our shared humanity causes you to bristle with indignation ‚Ä¶ you might want to be curious about why that is.‚Äù

Still others found the original post to be a toothless declaration that did not go far enough. ‚ÄúStatements like these are in fact extensions of the subversive violence that attempts to erase the genocide,‚Äù a representative for Writers Against the War on Gaza (WAWOG), a group of media and academic professionals that mobilize protests and campaigns in support of Palestine, told Hyperallergic via email.

‚ÄúGaza is being starved and annihilated by Israel, and it should be called what it is,‚Äù they continued. ‚ÄúAnything else is hollow prevarication.‚Äù

Hyperallergicvia Instagram)

The Holocaust Museum LA deleted the post on Saturday and issued an apology, stating that it ‚Äúwill ensure that posts in the future are more thoughtfully designed and thoroughly vetted.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe recently posted an item on social media that was part of a pre-planned social media campaign intended to promote inclusivity and community that was easily open to misinterpretation by some to be a political statement reflecting the ongoing situation in the Middle East,‚Äù the museum‚Äôs post said. ‚ÄúThat was not our intent. It has been removed to avoid further confusion.‚Äù

A representative for the museum declined to comment on the motivation behind the original post and its deletion, telling Hyperallergic that the new statement ‚Äúreflects the thought and purpose behind the original post.‚Äù

The museum‚Äôs decision to remove a post that many saw as a vague show of solidarity with the mass killings of Palestinians from an institution representing Holocaust survivors has sent ripples of outrage across the arts and culture world. Although comments were turned off on the museum‚Äôs apology post, observers from the realms of art, politics, and activism took to various platforms to express their dismay with the institution‚Äôs turnaround.¬†

title: The Works on Water Triennial Puts Commitment Over Spectacle
excerpt: A group show on an island a boat ride away from Manhattan is unlikely to attract the same attention as flashier happenings on the city‚Äôs busy fall art calendar , yet their work is no less deserving of it. The Works on Water (WoW) Triennial at the Arts Center at Governors Islan‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
A group show on an island a boat ride away from Manhattan is unlikely to attract the same attention as flashier happenings on the city‚Äôs busy fall art calendar, yet their work is no less deserving of it. The Works on Water (WoW) Triennial at the Arts Center at Governors Island, now in its third iteration, has been led since 2017 by a resourceful group of artists and curators (Emily Blumenfeld, Carolyn Hall, sTo Len, Clarinda Mac Low, Nancy Nowacek, and Sarah Cameron Sunde, at present). The collective remains oriented toward humble grassroots projects, such as performance artist Nora Almeida‚Äôs and videographer iki nakagawa‚Äôs collaborative multimedia explorations of Brooklyn‚Äôs Coney Island Creek.

This and other projects are compelling in their own right, but what stands out about their 2025 triennial is how many artists, and even artworks, have returned from the first two editions. This apparent repetitiveness may seem strange given that many bi- and triennials aspire to be cultural status updates. But WoW‚Äôs willingness to revisit projects indicates that it values art for its depth and persistence rather than how it sets or fits trends.

That commendable commitment is evident in ‚ÄúWalking the Edge‚Äù (2020‚Äì25), a preliminary version of which appeared in the previous WoW triennial and which here appears as a dense grid of shoreline photographs. The photos document an ambitious durational feat: From May to October 2025, in collaboration with Culture Push and NYC‚Äôs Department of City Planning, WoW members are leading walks covering the city‚Äôs entire 520 miles of coastline.

Video documentation of Sarah Cameron Sunde‚Äôs ‚Äú36.5 / A Durational Performance with the Sea‚Äù (2013‚Äì22) ‚Äî in which the artist and local participants stand in coastal waters for one full tidal cycle at sites around the world ‚Äî also makes a repeat appearance. Sunde‚Äôs performance, oriented toward deep time, patiently bears witness to the accelerating rate of sea level rise. The horizon-long Great Lakes vistas in Jana Harper‚Äôs short video, ‚ÄúSong for Water‚Äù (2025), likewise operate in a pensive, almost oracular, register.

It‚Äôs not surprising that Water Art, as WoW calls it, would take the long view of things, given the philosophical depth associated with its subject. But this triennial‚Äôs design emphasizes contemplative aesthetic gestures over the nitty-gritty logistics of its community projects, from sTo Len‚Äôs 30-foot-long gomitaku ‚Äî a Japanese portmanteau meaning ‚Äútrash impression‚Äù ‚Äî mono print that undulates across the gallery like an elegant serpent (‚ÄúImpressions for Coastal Constellation Alignment: Potomac River, Virginia,‚Äù 2020), to the floor-to-ceiling netting and cotton saris that Elizabeth Velazquez and Monica Jahan Bose use, respectively, to demarcate circular spaces (‚ÄúCalling Forth The Waters That Surround Us‚Äù and ‚ÄúDarchira River,‚Äù both 2025).

However counterintuitive emphasizing aesthetics over logistics might sound, it constitutes an effective solution to the problem of how to translate public and social practice art into a gallery setting. The triennial ‚Äî¬†especially the moody basement gallery suffused with a scent by perfume maker Frank Bloem (‚ÄúZeelucht (A Perfume from Forty Smells of the North Sea),‚Äù 2021) ‚Äî¬†reminded me of the dramatic installation environments in this summer‚Äôs inaugural Sky High Farm biennial, an eco-minded Hudson Valley show. But whereas the Sky High installations evince showmanship, WoW‚Äôs installations evince introspection. Nobody in the group has given up on doing the work ‚Äî quite the contrary ‚Äî but there‚Äôs an ambient sense that, given what has and hasn‚Äôt changed in the world since 2017, progress‚Äôs horizon might be further off than one would hope.

The Works on Water 2025 Triennial continues at the Arts Center of Governors Island (110 Andes Road, Manhattan) through October 26. The exhibition was curated by Emily Blumenfeld and Kendal Henry with the Works on Water team (Carolyn Hall, sTo Len, Clarinda Mac Low, Nancy Nowacek, and Sarah Cameron Sunde).

title: Emily Kam Kngwarray‚Äôs Language of Country
excerpt: LONDON ‚Äî An exquisite rhythm rolls across the sheer mass of Emily Kam Kngwarray‚Äôs paintings, produced in prolific bursts of creativity between 1980 and 1996, the last decade and a half of her life. As she worked at the forefront of a movement that sought to translate millennia‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
LONDON ‚Äî An exquisite rhythm rolls across the sheer mass of Emily Kam Kngwarray‚Äôs paintings, produced in prolific bursts of creativity between 1980 and 1996, the last decade and a half of her life. As she worked at the forefront of a movement that sought to translate millennia-old Aboriginal cultural traditions onto media such as acrylic, canvas, and batik, much of her oeuvre is marked by a strong visual cohesion. Colorful fields of dots and linear motifs in earthy tones proliferate across the entirety of each picture plane, often covering the edges of the canvases, creating an impression of an expansiveness that seems to incorporate both microcosm and macrocosm, landscape and human, ancestral time and contemporary pressures.

Kngwarray was an Anmatyerr woman born in Alhalker, in what is now known as the Northern Territory of Australia. An important Elder within her community, she is credited with breaking down the distinctions between fine art, craft, and cultural practice, gaining international recognition for her contribution to contemporary art. Her paintings and batik silks are inextricably rooted in the lands on which she was born, which in her earliest years were untouched by White settlers. However, when she was a child, they colonized Alhalker, and their introduction of sheep, cattle, and fences irrevocably changed her people‚Äôs Country.

This concept of ‚ÄúCountry‚Äù is key to understanding Kngwarray‚Äôs work and the culture in which she developed her practice. As an explanatory wall text puts it, ‚ÄúFor Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, the concept ‚Ä¶ encompasses the lands, skies and waters to which they are deeply connected, over countless generations. Country is a shared place of spiritual, social and geographical origins.‚Äù In Kngwarray‚Äôs paintings, such as ‚ÄúAnkerr (Emu)‚Äù (1989), this manifests as a map-like depiction of emu footprints emerging from a web of patterns and dots, charting the routes taken by the birds between underground water sources.

Kngwarray‚Äôs work also draws closely on Dreamings: ancestral beings who manifest in the plants, animals, and natural phenomena of Country. Dreamings are intrinsic to Kngwarray‚Äôs worldview and practice, with a focus on animals and plants which are special to her, including the ankerr (emu) and anwerlarr (pencil yam). Yet in Western contexts, such traditions have too often been exoticized, flattening their complexity and cultural significance. The Tate show doesn‚Äôt openly refer to previous Western cultural or curatorial practices in relation to art by Aboriginal peoples, but it does take pains to explicate the respectful approach used throughout this show, using terms like Country and Dreaming without romanticization, and applying spellings of Anmatyerr words deemed appropriate by Kngwarray‚Äôs family and community. In addition, the exhibition texts use Aboriginal place names alongside English ones, as well as Anmatyerr words for the plants and animals Kngwarray depicts.¬†

Some of Kngwarray‚Äôs paintings relate to Awely, women‚Äôs ceremonies celebrating certain animals or plants, in which they grind pigments to paint dots and patterns on each other‚Äôs bodies. Included in the exhibition is a video in which Kngwarray‚Äôs family members perform one such ceremony; they also contributed to the curating and textual interpretation of the exhibition. The show draws convincing parallels between these rituals and the texture, techniques, and patterning of some of the large-scale works displayed nearby, such as ‚ÄúAlhalker ‚Äì My Country‚Äù (1992), a heavily layered tall panel dotted with shades of rust and ocher. Swirling patterns emerge and fade before the viewer‚Äôs eyes, recalling the cyclical verses of ceremonial songs, or the tradition of temporary sand drawings made by women to tell stories.

title: 30 Ways to Romanticize Your Life This Fall
excerpt: I‚Äôve always said that fall makes me feel the most myself. The season invites stillness, reflection, and a slower pace that‚Äôs hard to come by in summer‚Äôs chaos. The air feels sharper, the light softens, and there‚Äôs a certain beauty in the shift that asks us to pause and savor.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I‚Äôve always said that fall makes me feel the most myself. The season invites stillness, reflection, and a slower pace that‚Äôs hard to come by in summer‚Äôs chaos. The air feels sharper, the light softens, and there‚Äôs a certain beauty in the shift that asks us to pause and savor.

At Camille Styles, we often talk about what it means to romanticize life. For us, it isn‚Äôt about chasing an aesthetic or curating a picture-perfect day. Instead, it‚Äôs a practice of presence‚Äîchoosing to notice the beauty in small rituals and finding joy in the ordinary. This idea has made its rounds on TikTok and Pinterest, but we think fall is when it truly comes to life.

How to Romanticize Fall: 30 Cozy Ideas to Embrace the Season

Here‚Äôs the truth: romanticizing fall doesn‚Äôt mean escaping reality. It means leaning into it‚Äîwelcoming the season‚Äôs rhythms, flavors, and textures, and allowing them to nourish us. From the golden glow of an early sunset to the familiar comfort of pumpkin bread in the oven, these are the moments that ground us in the season and remind us of what‚Äôs good.

Why Fall Is the Season for Slowing Down

Autumn has a way of nudging us inward. As the days grow shorter and the air turns crisp, the expansive energy of summer naturally gives way to a quieter, more grounded rhythm. It‚Äôs not just the cooler weather or the changing leaves‚Äîit‚Äôs the gentle invitation to be more wholly here.

This season, especially, feels made for mindfulness. Fall is abundant with sensory details: the scent of cinnamon, the crunch of leaves, the softness of a favorite sweater pulled from storage. These simple rituals carry a kind of poetry and invite us to experience the season more fully. It‚Äôs choosing to find beauty in the ordinary and allowing the smallest pleasures to anchor us in the moment.

30 Ways to Romanticize Fall

With that spirit in mind, I‚Äôve compiled simple and intentional ways to embrace the season. If you‚Äôre ready to embrace the softer side of autumn, here are 30 ideas for how to romanticize fall‚Äîand in doing so, rediscover the joy of slowing down.

Cozy Rituals at Home

1. Savor a cup of chai by the window. Let the warm spices wrap around you as you watch the leaves fall. This is my favorite recipe‚Äîit‚Äôs perfectly spicy and sweet.

2. Light a candle in the early morning. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I love sleeping in. But in the fall, there‚Äôs something magical about leaning into this quiet ritual that brings a soft glow to the stillness of your waking moments.

3. Reread a favorite book under a blanket. There‚Äôs a reason certain stories feel like autumn companions‚Äîreturning to them can feel like visiting an old friend. These beautifully written books do just the trick.

4. Play a vinyl record instead of streaming music. The warm crackle of sound sets a nostalgic and cozy tone.

5. Journal with a cup of tea. Reflect on the season‚Äôs shifts, your rhythms, and what you want to release (and welcome in) before the year ends.

6. Bake something spiced just because. No occasion needed‚Äîlet cinnamon and nutmeg fill the air, and enjoy the comfort of fresh-from-the-oven warmth. Let your fall baking marathon commence.

7. Take a midday bath. Warm water, eucalyptus steam, and no rush‚Äîlet yourself be indulgent in the middle of the day.

8. Rearrange your space for the season. Swap lighter linens for cozy throws, tuck fresh branches into vases, and create a reading nook that feels like autumn itself.

9. Start a seasonal playlist. Soft jazz, acoustic covers, or instrumental roundups that feel like they belong to golden hours and candlelight.

10. Write a letter by hand. Slow down enough to connect with someone the old-fashioned way, with pen, paper, and intention.

Seasonal Food & Drinks

11. Bake an apple crumble. A warm and comforting dessert that requires no perfection‚Äîjust a love for seasonal fruit and crunchy topping. Bonus: this recipe couldn‚Äôt be easier.

title: A Gut-Healthy Meal Plan, But Make It Delicious
excerpt: If you haven‚Äôt yet subscribed to my Substack, it‚Äôs where I get a little more personal‚Äîwriting from the heart about self-care, motherhood, wellness, and all things in between.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
If you haven‚Äôt yet subscribed to my¬† Substack, it‚Äôs where I get a little more personal‚Äîwriting from the heart about self-care, motherhood, wellness, and all things in between.

This post resonated with our community there, so today I wanted to share an excerpt with you here.

‚ÄúHealthy eating‚Äù means different things to different people, and I truly believe there‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all approach. Our bodies and lifestyles are unique‚Äîespecially when it comes to eliminating foods like gluten and dairy. Yes, many people have food sensitivities‚Äîbut not everyone, so experiment with the way of eating that makes you feel best before you start cutting things out. What works for one person may or may not work for you.

That said, certain foods are powerful in nourishing your gut, boosting the good bacteria, and supporting digestion. What you eat directly influences your microbiome‚Äîand a healthy microbiome can help reduce inflammation, protect against chronic disease, enhance brain health, and support weight loss.

Specifically, I focus on:

  • Whole, unprocessed foods
  • Fiber-rich ingredients
  • A wide variety of plants (the more diversity, the better for your microbiome!)
  • Healthy fats like salmon, avocado, and olive oil
  • Prebiotic and probiotic-rich foods

Research shows¬†that diversifying your plate can improve your microbiome in as little as 24 hours.

Okay, enough science‚Äîlet‚Äôs talk about what to eat! Don‚Äôt know about you, but I love a good meal plan. It‚Äôs easy to get stuck in a cooking rut, and a balanced meal plan can inspire you to try new ingredients and flavors‚Äîand help reduce food waste, since you‚Äôre grocery shopping for specific meals.

So, here‚Äôs the plan:

  • Each recipe in this meal plan emphasizes digestion-friendly ingredients, high fiber, and colorful fruits and veggies to nourish your microbiome and keep your gut happy all week long.
  • Breakfast and lunch are all about simplicity. (I tend to pick a lunch and repeat it throughout the week!) Choose one or two recipes to prep ahead, or mix it up with dinner leftovers‚Äîall the dinners (except the tacos) are great reheated as lunches. title: How to Reset This September (Without Overhauling Your Whole Life)

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
This summer unraveled me. Between cross-country flights, caregiving for my father, and toggling between Oregon and New England, I felt suspended. It was like living in two worlds at once, never fully grounded. As the season shifts, I‚Äôm not just welcoming cooler air and longer shadows‚ÄîI‚Äôm noticing the crispness in the mornings, the golden light spilling across my Portland streets, and how the sunlight catches in my eyes in a way that makes me feel fully awake again. I‚Äôm craving a September reset: a return to rhythm, to rituals, and to a steadiness that feels like home.

Fall has always been my season of becoming. Summer‚Äôs spontaneity is beautiful in its own way, but it can leave me untethered, spinning from one thing to the next. This year, my intention isn‚Äôt to return to who I was before. It‚Äôs to step into someone new: rooted, aligned, and intentional. My September reset is made up of small adjustments that help me find my footing again. These aren‚Äôt grand gestures or sweeping overhauls, but everyday practices that remind me I can always start anew.

How to Approach Your September Reset

A September reset doesn‚Äôt mean completely overhauling your life or chasing a brand-new version of yourself. After a summer that had me juggling travel and constant transitions, I‚Äôve realized the most meaningful shifts are subtle, small adjustments that help me feel centered and steady. They‚Äôre the practices I return to when I want to feel like a real and complete person again. (Not someone who‚Äôs‚Äîfrantically, chaotically‚Äîgoing through the motions.)

Think of this reset as a gentle guide rather than a checklist. The goal isn‚Äôt perfection‚Äîit‚Äôs alignment and a sense of reconnecting with your authentic self as the days grow cooler and the season turns.

10 Simple Changes to Inspire Your September Reset

As I step into fall, I‚Äôm focusing on the everyday practices that help me return to myself‚Äîclearing space, inviting presence, and creating the consistency I‚Äôve been craving. They‚Äôre not about reinventing my life, but about realigning with it in ways that feel manageable, meaningful, and (spoiler!) completely within reach.

1. Clear Space at Home

After a summer of suitcases and scattered piles, I need blank surfaces and organized drawers. The chaos of caregiving and travel left my home feeling more like storage than sanctuary. I‚Äôm starting small: a 20-minute tidy before bed, tackling one drawer at a time, and creating little pockets of calm.

Try it: Pick one surface and clear it completely. This could be your nightstand, desk, kitchen counter, etc. Notice how that small change improves your energy.

2. Reclaim Morning Rituals

This summer, my mornings belonged to everyone but me. Early flights (or recovering from late ones), appointments, and unpredictable schedules made starting the day with intention impossible. Now, I wake a bit earlier to make coffee, journal, or sit quietly by the window. Even five mindful minutes can anchor my day.

Try it: Before reaching for your phone, take a few deep breaths and ask yourself: How do I want to move through today?

3. Cook with the Season

After months of takeout and eating on the go, I‚Äôm craving meals that ground me. Not only that, but I miss the way shopping at the farmer‚Äôs market would make me feel connected, both to my local community and to myself. September markets are full of squash, apples, and late-summer tomatoes. Cooking with these ingredients feels like reestablishing roots, nourishing both body and soul.

Try it: Choose one seasonal recipe this week that invites slowness, like roasting vegetables or baking bread.

4. Move with Intention

This summer, I often pushed through exhaustion with long, intense workouts, thinking that more miles or higher intensity was the only way to feel strong. Now, as I train for my marathon, I‚Äôm learning to honor movement that feels purposeful and restorative: a focused run at a comfortable pace, a barre class to stretch and build strength, or a mindful walk through my neighborhood. Movement has become about experiencing presence in my body, not just sweat. It‚Äôs a practice that grounds me while still challenging me.

Which would you choose: a two-day journey to speak with a healthcare specialist for a cursory five minutes, or endless access to AI-powered reassurance? Viola Zhou examines the complicated relationship between her mother, who struggles with complications from chronic kidney disease, and DeepSeek, one of China‚Äôs most popular AI chatbots, from which she seeks medical guidance and comfort. Zhou‚Äôs reporting does essential work here, tempering industry hype around the medical expertise of large language models. But it‚Äôs her close study of her mother‚Äîher isolation and uncertainty, her desire for support and resolution‚Äîthat cinches this moving feature.

For patients like my mom, who feel they don‚Äôt get the time or care they need from their health care systems, these chatbots have become a trusted alternative. AI is being shaped into virtual physicians, mental-health

therapists, androbot companionsfor the elderly. For the sick, theanxious, theisolated, and many other vulnerable people who may lack medical resources and attention, AI‚Äôs vast knowledge base, coupled with its affirming and empathetic tone, can make the bots feel like wise and comforting partners. Unlike spouses, children, friends, or neighbors, chatbots are always available. They always respond.

Entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, and even some doctors are now pitching AI as a salve for overburdened health care systems and a stand-in for absent or exhausted caregivers. Ethicists, clinicians, and researchers are meanwhile warning of the risks in outsourcing care to machines. After all, hallucinations and biases in AI systems are prevalent. Lives could be at stake.

Over the course of months, my mom became increasingly smitten with her new AI doctor. ‚ÄúDeepSeek is more humane,‚Äù my mother told me in May. ‚ÄúDoctors are more like machines.‚Äù

Nearly 20 years ago, Michelle Vanek disappeared while climbing Holy Cross, one of ‚ÄúColorado‚Äôs most iconic fourteeners.‚Äù The trek was considered a nontechnical but particularly arduous climb, especially for a novice. For 5280 Magazine, Heather Hansman reports on how a day trip went horribly wrong, turning into the ‚Äúlargest search for a missing hiker in Colorado history,‚Äù and why it took nearly two decades to solve the mystery.

It‚Äôs not uncommon for hikers to run into trouble on Holy Cross. Vail Mountain Rescue responds to about 15 individuals or groups there each year. Scott Beebe, a longtime member of the team, says hikers tend to get confused near the summit. Instead of taking the correct route to the North Ridge trail, which looks steep from the top, they can mistakenly head down mellower-looking paths that actually dead-end above cliffs. The searchers traced these and many other routes, looking for Vanek, to no avail. A few days in, snow began to fall. By the eighth, when rescuers were trudging through two feet of powder, the search was called off. Everyone was baffled. ‚ÄúWe ended up the last day with not a clue, not a gum wrapper, not a boot print, absolutely nothing,‚Äù wrote searcher Tim Cochrane in his report to the sheriff. ‚ÄúHow can anyone just vanish into thin air?‚Äù

title: A Missing Child of the 1980s, All Grown Up

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
A Missing Child of the 1980s, All Grown Up

Scott Rankin‚Äôs father hatched an elaborate plot to kidnap him and start a secret life, while his mother searched desperately for six years. That was only the start of Scott‚Äôs traumatic life journey.

One morning in 1984, the school principal walked into the classroom where I taught fourth grade and whispered to me, ‚ÄúScott is a missing child!‚Äù

I looked at 9-year-old Scott, who was present in my class that day. I was quite aware what was implied. The term ‚Äúmissing child‚Äù had been seared into the nation‚Äôs psyche in the 1980s following a few high-profile cases, including the kidnapping and murder of 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979. None of us at the school had any idea that Scott had been kidnapped from his own home just a few months before Patz.

The principal explained that Scott had been kidnapped by his father, and over the past six years, including the four-plus he‚Äôd been enrolled in our school, his mother, who lived on the other side of the country, had been desperately searching for him. I did not know the depth of the story beginning to unfold. It would be weeks before I understood the immediate implications for Scott and his family ‚Äî and decades before I learned of the full dimensions of Scott‚Äôs remarkable experience.

12/29/78, I picked up Scott on time. Martha knows nothing. Today is the day‚Ä¶I have reached the point of no return.

The 2025 MTV VMAs were, as usual, a star-studded affair. This year, some of those stars used their moments in the spotlight to uplift LGBTQ people.

Singers Sabrina Carpenter and Ariana Grande both made headlines for their demonstrations and words in support of trans and gay individuals.¬†

The biggest moment came in the form of Carpenter‚Äôs performance of ‚ÄúTears.‚Äù She was joined onstage by numerous drag queens, including Honey Balenciaga, Symone, Jewels Sparkles and Denali. And at the end of the song, performers carried large signs reading, among other pro-LGBTQ messages, ‚Äúprotect trans rights‚Äù and ‚ÄúIn Trans We Trust.‚Äù

Following the performance, viewers took to social media to laud her (and other allied celebrities) for ‚Äúshowing constant support to the trans community and showcasing drag queens in their biggest projects,‚Äù which, they added, is ‚Äúso important in this political state.‚Äù

Grande, meanwhile, ended her acceptance speech for the biggest award of the night ‚Äì Video of the Year ‚Äì by thanking ‚Äútherapists and gay people‚Äù for their roles in supporting her success. ‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù she added.

It‚Äôs not the first time either performer has been vocal about supporting the community. Just this past June, Carpenter raised $1 million to support a variety of nonprofits that offer mental health and suicide prevention services to LGBTQ people. Grande, meanwhile, spoke out in January in support of trans individuals amid the slurry of anti-trans executive orders signed by President Donald Trump when he re-assumed the office.

And both of them signed an open letter written by The Trevor Project, a nonprofit focused on suicide prevention among young people who identify as part of the LGBTQ community. The letter was written in protest of the Trump administration‚Äôs defunding of a crisis hotline.

While speaking with Forbes earlier this year, Carpenter plainly laid out the drive behind such public displays of support. ‚ÄúI want to send so much love to my LGBTQ+ fans,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve always shown up for me, and I‚Äôm committed to showing up for you.‚Äù

title: The Biggest Threat to Women‚Äôs Lives: The Men They Know
excerpt: Pexels )
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Pexels)

According to a new study, a woman‚Äôs safety is most compromised by the men in her life.

The Femicide Census, a UK-based organization that researches the circumstances around women‚Äôs murders, found through its research efforts that women are most likely to be killed by male partners ‚Äì especially while trying to leave those relationships ‚Äì and sons.

Women are far less imperiled by male strangers, the study adds, as just 9% of the murders they researched for this latest report were committed by men the victims didn‚Äôt know. Rather, the majority of the women whose deaths were studied (70%) were killed in their own homes.

The organization‚Äôs executive director, Dr. Karen Ingala Smith, noted to BBC News that, for every woman who was murdered by a man she knew, ‚Äúmany more [are] living with and enduring serious violence and abuse‚Äù.¬†

Though the Census looks at deaths that occurred in the UK, other studies have shown this trend to be true the world over. A 2024 report from UN Women indicated that of the 85,000 girls and women murdered by men in 2023, 60% were killed by a man who was close to them.

‚ÄúWhat the data is telling us is that it is the private and domestic spheres of women‚Äôs lives ‚Äì where they should be safest ‚Äì that so many of them are being exposed to deadly violence,‚Äù Nyaradzayi Gumbonzvanda, UN Women‚Äôs deputy executive director, told the Guardian. And what‚Äôs worse, she adds, is that ‚Äúwe see the numbers in this report as the tip of the iceberg.‚Äù

Smith, of the Femicide Census, says that sharing this information could be life-saving in and of itself ‚Äì and hopes government officials act to quell the violence. In the UK, the Labour Party, now in power, has pledged to halve serious violence ‚Äì including men‚Äôs violence against women ‚Äì in 10 years.

‚ÄúThey are going to have to act fast and ambitiously to even approach that target,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúMen who are known to be a danger to women are too frequently at liberty to harm, rape and kill.‚Äù

A group of sexual assault survivors joined a pair of U.S. House members to demand transparency from President Donald Trump and the U.S. Justice Department around the latter‚Äôs investigation into deceased financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

Led by Democratic Rep. Ro Khanna of California and Republican Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky, the cohort stood outside of the U.S. Capitol building Wednesday afternoon to call for a release of the Justice Department‚Äôs full records ‚Äì beyond the pages released Tuesday, many of which had already been made public.

‚ÄúToday ‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre united in restoring trust in government. We‚Äôre here not as partisans, we‚Äôre here as patriots,‚Äù Khanna said at the press gathering.

She and Massie are going about their pursuit for the files through atypical means: By filing a discharge petition, which would force a Congressional vote on the release of information if they can get 218 signatures from fellow House members. In a show of bipartisan support, Republican Reps. Marjorie Taylor Green, Lauren Boebert and Nancy Mace have already signed.

The cohort of survivors who spoke was bipartisan, too ‚Äì Haley Robsen, one of several women who took to the podium, identified herself as a registered Republican while addressing the public, adding, ‚Äúnot that that matters, because this is not political.‚Äù She called on Trump to remember the personhood of all of the survivors. ‚ÄúWe are real human beings. This is real trauma.‚Äù

Epstein, who died by suicide in August 2019, victimized hundreds of girls and women over the course of decades. British socialite Ghislaine Maxwell, a longtime associate of Epstein‚Äôs, was convicted for her involvement in the mass trafficking and assault in 2021. The two are known to have relationships with many high-profile folks ‚Äì from Trump himself, to British royal Prince Andrew and former President Bill Clinton ‚Äì making Epstein‚Äôs client list of particular public interest.

In response to the demonstration, Trump dismissed the collective call for openness as a ‚ÄúDemocrat hoax that never ends.‚Äù He continued, while speaking to members of the press from the Oval Office: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre trying to get people to talk about something that‚Äôs totally irrelevant to the success that we‚Äôve had as a nation since I‚Äôve been president.‚Äù

The survivors have their own interpretation of such stonewalling. ‚ÄúThe only motive for opposing this would be to conceal wrongdoing,‚Äù said Anouska De Georgiou, one of those gathered before the press on Wednesday.

She then added, ‚ÄúYou have a choice: Stand with the truth ‚Äì or with the lies that have protected predators for decades.‚Äù

title: Two Hospital Moments I‚Äôm Looking Forward to When My Baby Arrives
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
This photo was taken before our son Emiliano arrived. Max didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd really go into labor at 32 weeks that day so he dressed for work, just in case!

Today, I am 35 weeks pregnant. I just felt a smooth rolling feeling underneath my belly as baby girl pressed her leg or arm up against me. Every week, her presence feels more real, and we‚Äôve been preparing for her arrival by making room in her big sister‚Äôs bedroom and packing our hospital bag. But what‚Äôs also been taking up lots of brain space are two sweet labor-and-delivery moments‚Ä¶

The first one is introducing our two older kids ‚Äî¬†Ella and Emiliano ‚Äî¬†to their little sister. This Instagram reel has smart tips for that special moment. I love how the baby is in the bassinet when his older brother walks into the hospital room, and how his mom has her arms open to snuggle him in. Also the family group hug at the end? C‚ÄôMON.

But my favorite part? The parents taped photos of the boy into the baby‚Äôs bassinet. That gesture created a space for him to feel loved and seen. It also showed him how excited his sister was to meet him. Isn‚Äôt that such an easy but beautiful tip?

Ella and Emiliano never had their meeting-for-the-first-time-in-the-hospital moment because after he was born, he spent the next month in the NICU, and they didn‚Äôt allow visitors under the age of 14. So, they first met at home, which is one of the greatest memories of my life. But this time around ‚Äî if all goes smoothly with this delivery and my two children get to visit us in the hospital ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hang their pictures in the bassinet so they feel a sense of connection with their new sister.

***

The second post-delivery moment I‚Äôm mustering up the courage to do is take a photo with my labor and delivery nurse. Whenever someone asks about my birth stories I ALWAYS talk about the nurses who helped me. These women! So kind and gentle, they were the safeguards of my body and soul in a moment that felt sacred but scary.

I‚Äôll never forget the nurse who took care of me while I labored with Emiliano. She let me squeeze her hands as hard as I could when I got my epidural. And when I flinched with contractions, she pet my hair and led me through breathing exercises. She even stayed past her shift to see Emiliano arrive and write down his weight and height measurements on his baby tag.

Whenever I think of her, I tear up, and to this day, I regret not taking a photo with her. In the moment I felt too shy to ask and didn‚Äôt want to be a bother. But now I wish I could show a picture to Emiliano of the nurse who led me through one of the hardest moments of my life and helped bring him into this world.

If I‚Äôm lucky enough to meet another crew of caring labor and delivery nurses this time around, I‚Äôm going to go for it and ask for a quick selfie. Because these women and men are incredible, and play such a huge role in the moments we‚Äôll always remember.

If you‚Äôve delivered a baby, what labor and delivery moments did you find meaningful? Is there anything you‚Äôd recommend to others? I‚Äôd love to hear.

author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
I fell in love with Dan Pelosi last summer‚Ä¶

Of course, I was already a big fan of the Italian-American cookbook author, who lives in a gorgeous farmhouse upstate with his equally cute partner, Gus. We‚Äôd written on Cup of Jo about how Dan turns around a bad day, and he‚Äôd attended my holiday cookie swap (although he‚Äôs more famous for his own!).

But then, last summer, Toby and I went upstate and ran into Dan and Gus at an outdoor pizza spot, and they immediately shepherded us to their picnic table and were so warm and wonderful that Toby didn‚Äôt stop talking about them the whole drive home.

So! I‚Äôm thrilled to report that Dan has written a new cookbook ‚Äî Let‚Äôs Party: Recipes and Menus for Celebrating Every Day ‚Äî¬†which came out yesterday.

How sweet is the dedication page?

His book is full of entertaining showstoppers, like steak over frites‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶simple favorites, including a green salad with shallot dressing‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶and sweet treats. And, today, to celebrate tomato season and his cookbook, Dan has agreed to share his panzanella recipe. ‚ÄúYou know that board game, Operation?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIf it were based on me, you‚Äôd see a tomato where my heart should be.‚Äù

Tuscan Panzanella Salad
from Dan Pelosi‚Äôs Let‚Äôs Party: Recipes and Menus for Celebrating Every Day
Serves 6 to 8

Says Dan: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always said panzanella salad is just a bread basket in drag. It‚Äôs the same satisfying taste of ripping apart a dinner roll and running it through vinegary oil but dressed up for the evening gown portion of the night. This salad began as Tuscan peasant food, a very smart way to get an extra meal out of stale loaves. Now you‚Äôll find it with luxury accessories like cheese, stone fruits, or all kinds of proteins. When the tomatoes mingle with onions, red wine vinegar, oil, and plenty of salt and pepper, you‚Äôve got everything you need in the world.‚Äù

3 pounds of heirloom tomatoes, cut into 1-inch pieces
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 large red onion, cut into 1-inch pieces
1/4 cup red wine vinegar
1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for drizzling
1 (16-ounce) loaf crusty bread, torn into 1-inch pieces

Preheat the oven to 400¬∞F. Place the tomatoes (and any collected juices from the cutting board) in a large bowl and add a few big pinches of salt and plenty of pepper. Toss gently to mix. Add the onion along with the vinegar and olive oil. Toss again.

On a rimmed sheet pan, drizzle the bread with a little bit of olive oil and toss to coat. Toast in the oven for about 10 minutes, until lightly golden. Remove and let the bread cool on the sheet pan, about 15 minutes.

Just before serving, add the bread to the bowl and toss to coat in the juices. Taste for seasoning and serve immediately.

Note: To make ahead, the bread can be toasted and stored in an airtight container at room temperature up to three days.

Thank you so much, Dan! You can find his new cookbook here, if you‚Äôd like.

title: These 4 Vibrant US Lake Towns Still Feel Like Summer During The Fall
excerpt: Prime beach season may be all but over as temperatures slowly begin to dwindle along much of America's coastlines.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Prime beach season may be all but over as temperatures slowly begin to dwindle along much of America's coastlines.

However, there's a loophole to experience waterfront bliss this fall. Who said summer vibes have to end?

Many lake towns see a surge in summer as people max out their PTO and rent boats, jet skis, and maybe even send a flirty text to their one connection with a luxe lakeside cabin.

Now that summer is becoming more distant in the rearview mirror, there's a handful of vibrant lake towns not quite ready to shed their leaves.

Stretching from Arizona to Georgia, we at Travel Off Path are happy to reveal 4 sunny getaways with months of sun-drenched shores remaining, where you won't need to pack your favorite flannel:

Lake Havasu: Locals' Favorite Getaway

Not to be confused with the Grand Canyon's cascading Havasu Falls, Lake Havasu hugs the Arizona-California line and has become a popular getaway amongst locals from both states.

As much of the U.S. will see temps trickle into the 50s and 60s, you'll still have 90-degree days perfect for swimming, kayaking and boating.

The town's signature landmark, the London Bridge (that has yet to fall down much to Fergie's chagrin), becomes a lot less crowded as the party scene is largely back in class.

Enjoy sweeping views of mountain backdrops, beat the heat with numerous hiking trails to start your day, and check out the town's event calendar, where it seems something exciting is on the docket every week, such as the upcoming Taste of Havasu 2025 and the 54th Annual London Bridge Days Parade, both slated for October.

Canyon Lake: The ‚ÄúMaldives Of Texas‚Äù

On paper, ‚ÄúMaldives‚Äù and ‚ÄúTexas‚Äù seem to go together about as well as family dinners and politics, but there's always an exception to the rule with anything.

In this case, it's Canyon Lake roughly an hour or so from both Austin and San Antonio, though the surprisingly cultural town of New Braunfels, home to TikTok-famous Buc-ee's and Texans' favorite fall festival, Wurstfest, that makes for the best base.

Canyon Lake once went viral for its waters being so blue, people couldn't believe there was a hidden slice of paradise in the middle of Texas hence the ‚ÄòMaldives' moniker.

With rowdy college kids back in school, you can expect fewer crowds during the fall. Find a scenic beach, take a dip in the pristine waters, or go fishing or kayaking without the need to navigate hordes of boats and untz-untzing fist-pumpers.

Canyon Lake is still in the 90s until October. Then there's a gradual decline into the 70s in November.

Lake Charles: Louisiana's Surprising Hotspot ‚Äì Literally

New Orleans aside, where would you guess Louisiana's up-and-coming hotspot might be?

Perhaps Baton Rouge, Lafayette, or Monroe ‚Äî nope. It's lesser-known Lake Charles.

Dubbed ‚ÄúLouisiana's Playground‚Äù, it's home to flashy name-brand resorts and a plethora of thrills to enjoy a fun-filled getaway no matter the season.

As you can imagine, summers are sweltering down in the bayou, making fall arguably the best time to visit, especially with outdoor draws like the Creole Nature Trail, perfect for wildlife spotting, and Prien Lake Park, a go-to spot to take in glowing sunsets.

With temps hovering in the 70s and 80s, you might not make use of resort pools as much as you would in summer, but you can take advantage of far better rates.

The posh L'Auberge Casino Resort Lake Charles is going as low as $125 this fall, and Golden Nugget Lake Charles Hotel & Casino isn't far behind.

Macon, Georgia: Discover Southern Charm & Lakeside Serenity

If you haven't heard of Macon, that's okay. Spirit Airlines was set to put this town on the map with new flights, but then realized it's a tall task to anchor an airport when you don't have any money. Oops!

Since Spirit is exiting before they even arrive, the best way to get here is via Atlanta, roughly 80 miles away.

This charming town blends deep Southern history with ancient roots, from Native-built Ocmulgee Mounds to its later role as a Confederate hub.

title: Americans Are Traveling In Record Numbers To These 3 Lesser Known Destinations In Spain
excerpt: When you think of Spain, it's probably places like Andalusia, Catalonia, and the Balearics that first come to mind.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
When you think of Spain, it's probably places like Andalusia, Catalonia, and the Balearics that first come to mind.

Concentrating some of the country's top beaches and world-renowned landmarks, and boasting an unrivaled gastronomy and social scenes, these three regions are probably Spain's leading regions for tourism.

Given their undeniable popularity, you'd expect them to also lead in numbers as far as year-on-year growth goes, especially among Americans. Surprisingly, they're far from claiming the top spot.

The fastest-growing Spanish region in terms of overnight stays by U.S. tourists is, in fact, the lesser-known Extremadura, in the southwestern part of Spain:

Americans Now Flocking Into Extremadura

According to data published by Spain's National Statistics Institute, Extremadura has registered a record-breaking 45 percent increase in the number of American visitors between January and July of this year, compared to the same period in 2024.

For comparison purposes, it outperforms the runner-up region, the Balearic Islands, which is home to popular beach destinations like Mallorca, Menorca, and Ibiza (up 14 percent), and it's¬†significantly ahead of the national average of only 2 percent.

In actual figures, 15,587 overnight stays fulfilled by Americans were recorded in 2025. This does not mean, of course, Extremadura is now more popular as a destination than, say, Barcelona or Seville, but it does signify it's getting trendier at a surprisingly fast pace.

That being said, Extremadura is a vast region, steeped in history, and characterized by its millennia-old towns and mountainous terrain‚Äîso where could Americans possibly be headed?

City-specific visitation numbers haven't been provided, but we can take a wild guess and assume Extremadura's triad of culture-loaded cities:

Trujillo

One of Spain's best-kept secrets, Trujillo is the perfect starting point for exploring Extremadura.

Perched on a hill overlooking verdant plains, it is distinguished by its postcard-ready Old Town, virtually unchanged since the Middle Ages, a sturdy, imposing Trujillo Castle, which dominates the idyllic townscape, and architectural charm.

The Church of Santa Mar√≠a la Mayor is a prime example of Gothic and Renaissance architecture, whereas Conquistadors' Houses are a set of palatial complexes and dwellings that once belonged to explorers who first made landfall in the Americas.

Trujillo also feels quieter than your average Spanish destination, with smaller crowds and a slower-paced lifestyle, and if you love grilled meats, definitely add the Michelin Guide-listed Corral del Rey to your restaurant wishlist.

If you're looking for something a little more, you know,¬†medieval-themed¬†to go with the overall aesthetics of the place, El Medievo, best known for its pork sirloin with Serena cheese sauce, and delicious¬†torrija¬†with cinnamon ice cream.

C√°ceres

The shining gem in Extremadura's crown, C√°ceres, is widely considered a part of Spain's ensemble of¬†best-preserved medieval settlements.

Picture narrow cobblestone streets lined with centuries-old houses and taverns, pastoral plazas with storybook-like wishing wells, and monumental fortifications to top it off.

The Old Town, known locally as Ciudad Monumental, is entirely encircled by walls, built by the Moors upon their conquest of southwestern Spain, and it features a whopping 30 towers, several of which remain intact.

The most famous of these towers, Torre de Bujaco, commands a breathtaking panorama of the city's red-bricked roofs and whitewashed Baroque cathedral, though if you're hoping to soak up all that Old World allure whilst being in the center of the action, Plaza Mayor is where you should be headed.

Ringed by historic buildings, it is the best spot to grab some tapas and an off-season tinto de verano as you people-watch, and take in all the amazing details of the stone-built edifices that surround you‚Äîif we may add, the square's Cafeteria Chocolat's is home to the best pastries in town.

M√©rida

Informally considered the ‚ÄòRome of Spain', and the capital of Extremadura, M√©rida is one of the most referenced examples of a Roman-era city in Iberia.

It features theaters, temples, aqueducts, and even an urban layout that's largely preserved from Ancient Times.
