title: How to deal with a defiant child
excerpt: Editor‚Äôs Note: Kelly Wallace is CNN‚Äôs digital correspondent and editor-at-large covering family, career and life. Read her other columns and follow her reports at CNN Parents and on Twitter @kellywallacetv.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Editor‚Äôs Note: Kelly Wallace is CNN‚Äôs digital correspondent and editor-at-large covering family, career and life. Read her other columns and follow her reports at CNN Parents and on Twitter @kellywallacetv.

Story highlights

In the "Parent Acts" video series, CNN's Kelly Wallace asks parents to role-play

"You can really make defiant children very compliant," says a parenting expert

Just about every day, Angela Estes, a New York mom, finds herself asking her 5-year-old son, ‚ÄúWhy are you being so defiant?‚Äù

When she says it‚Äôs time to get dressed and head to school or when she gives the sign that playground time has come to an end, he has other ideas, said a frustrated Estes.

‚ÄúHe just wants to do what he wants to do, and I find it very hard to establish the authority that whether he wants to do it or not, it‚Äôs what we‚Äôre going to do,‚Äù she said.

Who can‚Äôt relate to that?

I remember a few months back when one of my daughters wouldn‚Äôt listen to me. I resorted to the old ‚ÄúGo to your room,‚Äù which didn‚Äôt work, either. She continued to remain defiant and disobey me until I checked out of the situation and ignored her.

Still, I wondered what the ‚Äúright‚Äù way to handle her behavior actually was. Estes struggles with the same question and has even tried giving her son choices, such as saying that either they leave the playground or he is ‚Äúchoosing‚Äù not to have any screen time at home.

‚ÄúI sort of end up running out of things to take away, and then I get frustrated and angry, and I don‚Äôt know what to do when I‚Äôve run out of things and he still doesn‚Äôt want to do it,‚Äù she said.

In the eighth installment of our CNN Digital Video series ‚ÄúParent Acts,‚Äù we asked parents to act out the defiance they experience in their children. We then had a parenting expert listen to their role-play and weigh in with advice.

Parenting strategist and licensed family therapist Tricia Ferrara listened to Estes and wondered whether she‚Äôs walking into situations with her son armed more with ‚Äúhope‚Äù than a real plan to deal with his behavior.

‚ÄúA suggestion ‚Ä¶ is kind of ‚Äòstrike when the iron is cold‚Äô concept,‚Äù said Ferrara, author of ‚ÄúParenting 2.0: Think in the Future, Act in the Now,‚Äù a guidebook for parents with step-by-step advice on how to strengthen their relationships with their children.

‚ÄúI feel like you‚Äôre working real hard when you‚Äôre in the heat of the moment but maybe not doing so much rehearsal outside of this World Series moment at the playground, when the stakes are really high,‚Äù she said to Estes.

Ferrara‚Äôs advice was for Estes to come up with a plan: Promise the playground for Friday afternoon but say that ‚Äúwe need to see ‚Äòbig boy behavior‚Äô on the way to getting there.‚Äù

She said Estes could then come up with a few ways he could show that ‚Äúbig boy behavior,‚Äù such as getting dressed by himself or putting his toys away. ‚ÄúIf he‚Äôs reluctant, remind him through that phrase. ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄòHow about some ‚Äúbig boy behavior?‚Äù ‚Äô ‚Äú

Ferrara, who has been in practice in the Philadelphia area for more than a decade, said a family mantra can also serve as a trigger for children on what they need to do. ‚ÄúIn my house, it was ‚ÄòFussing gets you nothing,‚Äô ‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSo if [my kids] started to fuss about something, I would say, ‚ÄòWhat does fussing get you?‚Äô And they would say, ‚ÄòNothing,‚Äô and then they would stop because it triggered them to say, ‚ÄòOh, yeah, I‚Äôm supposed to do X.‚Äô ‚Äù

The problem with labeling a child as ‚Äòdefiant‚Äô

Parents may be quick to label their children as ‚Äúdefiant,‚Äù but experts say that fails to recognize that what we do as parents can impact our child‚Äôs behavior.

title: Stop the meltdowns!

Editor‚Äôs Note: Kelly Wallace is CNN‚Äôs digital correspondent and editor-at-large covering family, career and life. Read her other columns and follow her reports at CNN Parents and on Twitter @kellywallacetv.

Story highlights

In "Parent Acts" video series, CNN's Kelly Wallace asks parents to role play

During meltdowns, parents should try to remain calm and communicate clearly, an expert says

In my house, we called it going boneless. That‚Äôs when my girls, as toddlers, would arch their backs, screaming uncontrollably, usually in a public place (of course!) and there was nothing my husband or I could do to satisfy them.

If you have kids and you‚Äôve experienced one of their meltdowns, you no doubt know what I mean and what it feels like at that moment, when you are a mixture of emotions ‚Äì embarrassed, frustrated, angry and completely at a loss for how to resolve the problem. Even bribery, which we know is never the way to go, doesn‚Äôt seem to work when your child is at wit‚Äôs end and unable to calm down.

We recently asked some parents to act out what their children do and say when they melt down as part of a new CNN Digital video series called ‚ÄúParent Acts.‚Äù Since we know parents tend to get the best advice and support from other parents, we thought it would be fun and helpful for parents to act out what their kids are doing when there is a problem, and then have a parenting expert listen to their role play and weigh in with advice.

Pauline Hilborn, a mom of two in New York City, describes herself as an expert on meltdowns based on the experiences of her daughter, who she says is ‚Äú7-years-old but sounds more like 13.‚Äù

Case in point: Hilborn‚Äôs daughter wanted a ponytail like the pop singer Ariana Grande, but felt like her mom didn‚Äôt do the ponytail properly and put it in the wrong place.

‚ÄúShe came out crying and said, ‚ÄòAriana Grande‚Äôs ponytail is here not here,‚Äô‚Äù said Hilborn, pointing to the place on her head where her daughter preferred the ponytail to go, not where it ended up.

‚ÄúI was at a loss for words,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI had no idea what to say but my husband said, ‚ÄòWell, she‚Äôs right you know,‚Äô which didn‚Äôt help the situation.‚Äù

Debi, another mother of two in Manhattan, says her 7-year-old has definitely had some tantrums. When I asked her son what a meltdown is, he told me it‚Äôs when you cry a lot. When I asked him to imitate one, he said he keeps screaming until his mom lets him have whatever it is that he wants at that moment.

‚ÄúI completely freeze in those situations,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI lose all rational sense of now what do I do ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know how to do it without bribing him, so I end up taking away things.‚Äù

Help is on the way

Tricia Ferrara is a licensed family therapist and parenting strategist who has been in private practice in the Philadelphia area for more than a decade. She‚Äôs also author of ‚ÄúParenting 2.0: Think in the Future, Act in the Now,‚Äù a guide book for parents with step-by-step advice on how to strengthen their relationships with their children.

Ferrara listened to our parent volunteers imitate exactly what their children do and say during a meltdown, and then offered her advice:

No. 1 ‚Äì Try to prevent it

Yes, you can actually prevent a meltdown, said Ferrara, a mom of two teens. Kids get tired and hungry, and then they can‚Äôt tell you what‚Äôs going on. ‚ÄúYou want to try and maybe not bring a child to places that trigger them,‚Äù and avoid outings at the end of the day when it‚Äôs still difficult for them to coordinate their emotions with their body, she said. (I wish I had this in mind that time I decided to take my kids, then 2 and 4, grocery shopping right before dinner time. Not a smart move.)

title: Setting limits for 'spoiled' kids
excerpt: Editor‚Äôs Note: Kelly Wallace is CNN‚Äôs digital correspondent and editor-at-large covering family, career and life. Read her other columns and follow her reports at CNN Parents and on Twitter @kellywallacetv.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Editor‚Äôs Note: Kelly Wallace is CNN‚Äôs digital correspondent and editor-at-large covering family, career and life. Read her other columns and follow her reports at CNN Parents and on Twitter @kellywallacetv.

Story highlights

In the "Parent Acts" video series, CNN's Kelly Wallace asks parents to role-play

Set and enforce limits, and let kids have some control over their own money, author says

More than 10 years ago, as I headed to one of my final OB/GYN appointments before my first daughter was born, I had a moment.

I saw a young girl ‚Äì she couldn‚Äôt have been older than 12 ‚Äì walking down the street with a large Pucci shopping bag, talking so rudely to her mother.

I cringed and thought, ‚ÄúWhat a spoiled brat,‚Äù and told myself I would do everything to make sure that I did not raise spoiled children.

Fast-forward 10 years, and there is very little chance that my sports-loving, T-shirt-wearing girls will ever be caught dead shopping in Pucci, so I don‚Äôt have to worry about that. Still, my children have so much more than I ever had when I was their age, and I admit I sometimes break down when they want something and plead over and over again, ‚ÄúPlease, please, can I have this?‚Äù

I know I‚Äôm not alone.

In the third installment of our new CNN Digital Video series ‚ÄúParent Acts,‚Äù we asked parents to act out why it‚Äôs so hard to say no to our kids when they want something, and then we had a parenting expert listen to their role play to weigh in with advice.

‚ÄúI feel like my children are never satisfied and happy with what they have, so that‚Äôs really, I think, that‚Äôs my issue,‚Äù said Laura Simms, a mom of three in Atlanta and owner of a public relations firm.

Tricia Ferrara is a licensed family therapist and parenting strategist who has been in private practice in the Philadelphia area for more than a decade.

‚ÄúIn a changing world, raising your child to think they must be statically happy is not helpful,‚Äù said Ferrara, author of ‚ÄúParenting 2.0: Think in the Future, Act in the Now,‚Äù a guidebook for parents with step-by-step advice on how to strengthen their relationships with their children. ‚ÄúChildren need a process for coping with and adapting to a changing environment. It‚Äôs up to us, as parents, to give them that process.‚Äù

As parents, Ferrara says, we want our kids to look at the world and think, ‚ÄúI want more,‚Äù but we want them to be able to do that in such a way that they realize that getting what they want is a result of their efforts and not from ‚Äúpoking at somebody else.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust folding and giving your children just what they want is not helpful for them over the long run,‚Äù Ferrara said. ‚ÄúI know for parents, sometimes it‚Äôs easier for them ‚Ä¶ but easy for you is not healthy for them. So teaching them or compelling them how to organize their energy toward a goal is critical. It‚Äôs a critical skill for now, but it‚Äôs a very critical skill for the future.‚Äù

When your child sees the ice cream truck and screams, ‚ÄúPlease, Mommy, you never let me get Mister Softee,‚Äù instead of breaking down and getting your child that ice cream, you could proactively offer your child ice cream ‚Äì but only after they show ‚Äúbig-kid behavior.‚Äù

For many little kids, the No. 1 thing they want is to feel like they‚Äôre growing up, said Ferrara, a mom of two teenagers. ‚ÄúSo incentivizing them to do behaviors that show they‚Äôre a big kid will get them the big-kid goodies.‚Äù

Why ‚Äòspoiled‚Äô is a sensitive word for parents

Most parents will admit that the single worst word that someone could use to describe their children ‚Äì the word that would feel like the biggest indictment of their parenting ‚Äì would be to call them ‚Äúspoiled,‚Äù said Ron Lieber, author of ‚ÄúThe Opposite of Spoiled: Raising Kids Who are Grounded, Generous and Smart About Money.‚Äù

title: Toxic chemicals are hiding in your house dust
excerpt: A new study reviewed all data on chemicals in house dust
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Story highlights

A new study reviewed all data on chemicals in house dust

A total of 45 chemicals were identified, with 10 found in 90% of US homes

The most common classes of chemicals found were phthalates and flame retardants

When was the last time you dusted your house?

Your answer could reveal a lot about your home habits, but the findings of a new study might have everyone upping their game ‚Äì and potentially keeping wet wipes and hand sanitizer nearby at all times.

Researchers at George Washington University say 45 toxic chemicals are found commonly in your house dust, with 10 of them lurking in 90% of homes across the country.

‚ÄúWe wanted to identify which chemicals were present at the highest exposure in homes,‚Äù said Dr. Ami Zota, an assistant professor of environmental occupational health who led the study. ‚ÄúSome chemicals were in virtually every dust sample.‚Äù

To reveal which potential toxins we‚Äôre being exposed to in the comfort of our own homes, Zota‚Äôs team analyzed all studies that have sampled indoor environments in the United States since 2000. They looked for the presence of potentially toxic chemicals and divided them into five classes of chemicals, two of which were found to be more common than the rest: phthalates and flame retardants.

‚ÄúMany of the top 10 fall into these two categories,‚Äù Zota said.

But when factoring in the wide range of chemicals we‚Äôre exposed to, small amounts can add up, she stressed.

Lurking in the dust

The chemicals found in dust samples came from a range of things typically found inside your home, including vinyl products ‚Äì such as flooring ‚Äì cosmetics, baby products, furniture and nail polish.

To understand how these chemicals are entering your home, it helps to understand where they are used. Phthalates make plastic softer and more flexible, so they tend to be found in vinyl (PVC) materials such as flooring, blinds and food packaging. Flame retardants help products meet flammability standards that are built into building codes, insurance requirements and fire regulations.

The other three classes of chemicals found in dust samples included environmental phenols, usually used as preservatives in personal care products like shampoo; fluorinated chemicals, used as stain- and water-repellent treatments for upholstery, carpets and clothes and in nonstick pans; and fragrances.

Only one chemical used in fragrances had been the topic of a study, meaning many more chemicals are likely to be present in dust with little insight into them, according to the researchers. ‚ÄúWe know very little about the health hazard of these fragrances,‚Äù said Zota.

But the researchers note that it is about more than exposure. For example, phthalates were detected in the highest concentrations in the study, but the chemicals found in flame retardants had the ‚Äúhighest estimated intake,‚Äù meaning they are more likely to enter the body.

‚ÄúYou can breathe it in and can absorb into your skin,‚Äù Zota said. ‚ÄúThese chemicals are not bound to the products, so they can migrate out.‚Äù

A risk to child development

One of the biggest concerns underlying the presence of these chemicals hiding in house dust is the fact that children are most likely to inhale or ingest them as they crawl around, touching things and inevitably placing their hands in their mouths multiple times a day.

‚ÄúEnvironmental insults during early development can have long-lasting adverse health effects that persist across the lifespan,‚Äù Zota said. Phthalate exposure in children ‚Äúcan increase risk of respiratory, behavioral and neurodevelopmental problems.‚Äù

Phthalates are also known to disrupt hormones inside the body, meaning they could cause reproductive problems.

‚ÄúWe know from lead that exposures are not acceptable,‚Äù said Dr. Asa Bradman, associate director for exposure assessment at the Center for Environmental Research and Child‚Äôs Health at the University of California, Berkeley, who was not involved in the new study.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a strong argument to reduce exposure to children whose brains are changing and bodies are developing.‚Äù

As for the study findings, Bradman noted that the reason phthalates were found to be most common in house dust was probably because most studies have been done on this class of chemicals.

Source: Read the full article

title: A four-day workweek could be hazardous to your health
excerpt: Work still needs to get done in the same amount of total time
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Story highlights

Work still needs to get done in the same amount of total time

Fatigue and stress accumulate over a longer-than-normal working day

Many employers and employees love the thought of a four-day workweek. Supposedly, a four-day work schedule allows workers extra time to pursue leisure activities and family togetherness. Spurred on by visions of spending more time at the beach, many people are now encouraging businesses to adopt this kind of work plan.

There are many purported advantages. Some authorities say that a four-day work schedule facilitates the ability to provide child care and assistance for the elderly.

Proponents of such ‚Äúcompressed‚Äù work schedules ‚Äì those in which employees work longer hours for fewer days of the week ‚Äî point to gains in productivity that result from decreased overhead costs, such as not having to keep the lights on when nobody is working. Additional cost savings can be obtained from reducing total weekly commuting time.

A variety of business have tested the four-day concept, including Amazon, Google, Deloitte and a host of smaller firms. Amazon announced in late August that it is experimenting with an even shorter workweek of 30 hours for select employees, who would earn 75 percent of their full-time salary, should they choose to opt in.

How on-call and irregular scheduling harm the American workforce

Many of the pilot programs have shown promising results. Statistics from the Society for Human Resource Management indicate that 31 percent of employees were in a compressed workweek schedule as of 2015. That‚Äôs the case, however, for only 5 percent of large companies.

This is an issue in which I have considerable experience. I have been studying the health effects of long working hours for nearly 30 years. All the studies point to the potential dangers that can occur as the result of the additional risks created when work demands exceed a particular threshold. Most of the studies I have performed suggest that the dangers are most pronounced when people regularly work more than 12 hours per day or 60 hours per week.

It sounded like a good idea

The idea of a four-day workweek is not new. Labor experts have been studying and advocating these approaches since the 1970s. For example, in 2008, researchers from Brigham Young University conducted a series of surveys among employees and community members to assess their perspectives about a four-day workweek. The researchers found that about four-fifths of the employees reported a positive experience working that type of schedule.

Based on these positive results, Utah‚Äôs governor enacted a mandatory four-day workweek for all state employees. The state‚Äôs goal was to curb energy costs, improve air quality, ensure that needed services would still be available (for instance, garbage collection) and help to recruit and retain state employees. In 2011, however, Utah reversed course, saying that savings never materialized.

Could flexible working hours be the answer to the sleep-loss epidemic?

Other research has also supported the development and adoption of compressed work schedules. A 1989 study found that compressed schedules (PDF) were related to high levels of job satisfaction and employees‚Äô satisfaction with their work schedules; supervisors also reported they were pleased with the four-day workweek schedules.

Are there hidden dangers?

Despite the widespread enthusiasm for a four-day week, I am not convinced that kind of schedule is beneficial for employees or for businesses. The primary problem with the idea is that whatever work needs to be done, needs to get done in the same amount of total time. Despite wishes to the contrary, there are still only 24 hours in a day.

The math is simple: working five eight-hour shifts is equivalent to working four 10-hour shifts. That‚Äôs true. But the implications of these schedules are different. The danger is in disregarding the health effects that can occur as a result of fatigue and stress that accumulate over a longer-than-normal working day.

title: Conservatives Want More Kids ‚Äì Yet Offer Only Prayers When Kids Are Gunned Down
excerpt: Earlier this year , the Trump administration launched a crusade to address falling birth rates in the United States, which they and other conservatives view as a matter of grave concern.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Earlier this year, the Trump administration launched a crusade to address falling birth rates in the United States, which they and other conservatives view as a matter of grave concern.

In order to galvanize families, and women in particular, into having more kids, they proposed everything from $5,000 birthing bonuses to menstruation classes, so people could better track their ovulation cycles ‚Äì instead of universal childcare, or other forms of study-backed, government-subsidized assistance.

And none of their proposals involved protecting our children from the gun violence that continues to plague the U.S., to a degree unheard of anywhere else in the world.¬†

We‚Äôve been reminded, this week, of how dangerous our schools are because of this problem, by a gutting mass shooting in Minneapolis. As of publication, two children died ‚Äì ages 8 and 10 ‚Äì and 17 people were injured when suspect Robin Westman (who also died, of a self-inflicted gunshot wound) opened fire during a morning mass at the city‚Äôs Annunciation Catholic School.

Of the 17 who were hurt, 14 were kids. Some of them were as young as 6 years old.

‚ÄúThese were American families,‚Äù Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey said during a press briefing. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt just say this is about ‚Äòthoughts and prayers‚Äô right now. These kids were literally praying.‚Äù

Yet that‚Äôs largely what conservatives, including President Donald Trump, had to offer in the wake of the attack. ‚ÄúPlease join me in praying for everyone involved,‚Äù Trump wrote on Truth Social, with Vice President JD Vance offering a similar call. ‚ÄúMy prayers are with everyone involved in this tragedy,‚Äù Attorney General Pam Bondi also posted.

The solution to our gun-violence epidemic should be to pass more stringent gun laws. Experts have found that the sheer tonnage of guns available in the U.S., and the ease with which they can be purchased, makes ours a deadlier, more dangerous nation to live in. And study after study has shown that gun violence could be curbed significantly through policy prescriptions.

But for this particular shooting, after praying for peace, conservatives found an alternative scapegoat: Transgender people. Despite the fact that the vast majority of mass shootings are committed by cisgender men, Westman was a trans woman, so some are using this shooting to further anti-trans agendas.

Attacking a community that is already subject to extreme discrimination, while refusing to enact legislation that would see gun violence lessened, and then offering boiler-plate calls for prayer in the aftermath‚Ä¶ None of this does anything to actually help the children they claim to want, the children they claim to care about.¬†

None of this helped 10-year-old Weston Halsne, who survived the Minneapolis shooting because his equally-young friend shielded him from gunfire, and was injured in the process. ‚ÄúIt was like, shots fired, and then we kind of, like, got under pews,‚Äù he recalled to members of the press. ‚ÄúThey shot through the stained glass windows I think, and it was really scary.‚Äù

Weston added that was praying for his friend‚Äôs recovery ‚Äì because it‚Äôs the only recourse he, a traumatized child, has in the U.S., where people with the power to enact laws that would protect children from shootings like this fail to do so over and over again.¬†

Conservative politicians and pundits continue to pressure women to bring more lives like Weston‚Äôs into this world, into this country ‚Äì while at the same time demonstrating a refusal to even try to keep them safe. Over 400 school shootings have taken place in the U.S. since the 1999 Columbine High School massacre, with dozens killed, hundreds injured and thousands traumatized by these attacks.

title: Suspending Monthly Economic Reports Would Be Really Bad for Women of Color
excerpt: Pexels )
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Pexels)

This story was originally reported by Chabeli Carrazana of The 19th. Meet Chabeli and read more of her reporting on gender, politics and policy.

Reliably on the first Friday of every month for the past 50 years, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has released data on how women of color are faring in the economy. It‚Äôs the only timely source of this demographic-level data.

Without it, economists and policymakers would have no way of knowing how economic policy is affecting marginalized groups of workers in real time. They‚Äôd be flying blind on how to help them.

But that‚Äôs just what President Donald Trump‚Äôs nominee to run the bureau is suggesting doing.

On August 1, Trump fired the head of the bureau, Erika McEntarfer, after BLS published one of the largest revisions to its data in decades. The revision showed that the economy was in fact weaker than previously reported, leading Trump to accuse McEntarfer of tampering with the data to make his administration look bad.

Revisions of economic data have also always been part of how BLS, an independent and nonpartisan agency, functions. The data is collected from surveys of employers and households, and then published in three waves. The surveys are voluntary, so not all responses come in on time. BLS publishes an initial release and then revises in the subsequent two months as more responses come in. It‚Äôs done this way to ensure that markets and economists get real-time data on the economy. Since the pandemic, BLS has been struggling with lagging response rates and a rapidly changing economy that has led to larger revisions.

The reports are still considered one of the most reliable sources of U.S. economic data in the world.

McEntarfer, who was appointed by former President Joe Biden and was confirmed in a nearly unanimous Senate vote, is a widely respected economist who had worked in the federal government under multiple administrations. Trump‚Äôs nominee to replace her, E.J. Antoni, is an economist at the conservative think tank the Heritage Foundation who contributed to Project 2025. Discussing the employment data earlier this month, Antoni suggested that until the data is ‚Äúcorrected,‚Äù ‚Äúthe BLS should suspend issuing the monthly job reports but keep publishing the more accurate, though less timely, quarterly data.‚Äù¬†

White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said earlier this week that the Trump administration had noted Antoni‚Äôs suggestions but intended to continue issuing the monthly reports.

‚ÄúI believe that is the plan, and that‚Äôs the hope, and that these monthly reports will be data that the American people can trust,‚Äù Leavitt said.

Losing timely economic data, particularly at a time when the economy is showing signs of softening, is bad for every group, economists told The 19th. But it could disproportionately impact women and women of color, who are often the first to feel the impact of weakness in the economy and serve as a bellwether of what is to come.

‚ÄúThe household survey is really the only source for intersectional employment data on a monthly basis. That means that for groups of women we and others have been watching especially closely during this period ‚Äî for example, disabled women, Black women, women veterans ‚Äî timely information about these groups would disappear,‚Äù said Katherine Gallagher Robbins, a senior fellow at the National Partnership for Women & Families who routinely analyzes the data.

The National Women‚Äôs Law Center, which also publishes its monthly analysis of women in the workforce using BLS‚Äô data, said in a statement that ‚Äúlosing this impartial data will undermine efforts to improve women‚Äôs economic wellbeing, damage the credibility and reliability of data coming from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and hurt overall efforts to objectively assess the health of our economy.‚Äù

title: It‚Äôs Hot As Heck. Here Are 7 Summery Beverages to Beat the Heat

body:
Drink Besa‚Äôs fruit punch flavored hard seltzer. (Credit: Courtesy of Drink Besa)

Summer has arrived. And with it, higher than ever temperatures, thanks to heat waves and rather ominous-sounding weather phenomenons like the heat dome. As temperatures soar from the East Coast to the West Coast, and folks gather for summer BBQs, backyard gatherings, beach trips and pool days ‚Äì ice cold beverages will be a necessity.¬†
So we‚Äôve compiled a list of summertime drinks from female entrepreneurs whose startup stories we‚Äôve enjoyed ‚Äì and who we think you should get to know. From ros√©, to flavored seltzers, to functional beverages packed with minerals and adaptogens,¬† there‚Äôs something here for everyone at the party to enjoy.

(All images courtesy of the companies.)

Drink Besa

Tori Brodsky has been leading the helm of Drink Besa since 2022. With a background in nutrition science, she became interested in making convenient drinks with quality ingredients, such as canned wine that‚Äôs, in fact, pretty darn good (we tried the ‚Äúsexy and bright‚Äù white wine). Drink Besa also offers a line of hard seltzers, which it says are among the first on the market to use organic wine instead of malt liquor or spirits. The 5% ABV drink comes in three flavors ‚Äì peach, fruit punch, and citrus ‚Äì and is, according to Brodksy, ‚Äúthe ideal summer beverage: Delicious, premium, and truly unique.‚Äù

Bow & Arrow Brewing Co.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt set out to be the first Native-woman-owned brewery in the United States, but I‚Äôm told we are,‚Äù says Shyla Sheppard, founder of Bow & Arrow Brewing Co. She and her partner, Missy Begay, take inspiration from the American Southwest, incorporating traditional Indigenous ingredients into their craft beers. Their beers, like ‚ÄúDance In and Out of The Beams of a Neon Moon‚Äù (a fruity IPA), and ‚ÄúCactuscolada‚Äù (a Pina Colada-inspired sour ale) are available in their Albuquerque, New Mexico, tap room¬† ‚Äì where they are served cold straight from the tap ‚Äì as well as other locations.

Heti

Dana Thompson, who built the celebrated Owamni restaurant, is now turning her attention to the functional beverage space. Her new business, Heti, is a health-conscious brand selling low-dose THC beverages. The name itself means ‚Äúhome‚Äù in Dakota; Thompson is a direct descendant of the tribe through her mother. Evoking a sense of place ‚Äî and the flavors of home ‚Äî is intentional. ‚ÄúI wanted something that resonated with what the people I know were asking for,‚Äù Thompson told The Story Exchange in a recent interview, especially women who wanted to relax with something other than wine. There is a home-related social-impact component to her business model in the works, as Thompson also plans to create hempcrete housing on tribal lands with some of the profits.

Trois Noix

Jaime Araujo says her Napa Valley winery, Trois Noix, was born from a lifelong love of wine. She‚Äôs not only passionate about what ends up in the bottle, ‚Äúbut also how it got there, what happens when it fills your glass, and how it can bring a table of people together.‚Äù And how‚Äôs this for a summertime drink: The winery‚Äôs Sonoma Valley Ros√©, made from pinot noir, contains aromas of papaya, just-ripe strawberry, and crushed rose petals. Reviewers on wine app Vivino called it ‚Äúlight-bodied with a tart plum finish‚Äù and ‚Äúvery refreshing.‚Äù Trois Noix recommends pairing with grilled seafood and summer vegetables ‚Ä¶ or just sipping on its own, if you don‚Äôt have grand cooking plans on the hazy horizon.

All Phenoms

Cristina Kown‚Äôs sparkling waters, All Phenoms, are packed with organic fruits and filled with vitamins, adaptogens, minerals, prebiotics and probiotics. Her aim? To offer a super healthy alternative to sugary sodas. The Redondo Beach, California-based entrepreneur is a self-proclaimed healthy beverage fan ‚Äì but was dismayed that most of the drinks on the market contained tons of sugar, or low-quality ingredients. We imagine All Phenoms drinks in flavors like berry hibiscus, citrus ginger and mango lemongrass would do a good job of keeping you sufficiently hydrated at any sweltering gathering.

title: Each Piece of Her Furniture is Tailored to Clients‚Äô Tastes
excerpt: Charlotte Wissel, founder of Artemis Virtu. (Credit: Courtesy of Artemis Virtu)
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Charlotte Wissel, founder of Artemis Virtu. (Credit: Courtesy of Artemis Virtu)

Charlotte Wissel‚Äôs design company, Artemis Virtu, collaborates with customers on crafting furniture that‚Äôs made to suit their individual tastes.

For Charlotte Wissel, furniture has always been about more than function or necessity ‚Äì it‚Äôs also an alternative form of expression. Wissel told us, ‚ÄúI see each piece as a blank canvas with the potential to become a work of art.‚Äù In 2020, the Fort Lauderdale, Florida, designer launched her company, Artemis Virtu, through which she aims to combine craftsmanship, storytelling and bold design into something tangible and lasting. Wissel also takes upholstery to another level by integrating custom materials and original artwork into every project.¬†

Here‚Äôs our lightly edited Q&A, from The Story Exchange 1,000+ Stories Project.

How is your business different from others in your industry?

We treat upholstery as an art form, not just a service. While many upholstery businesses focus solely on repair or restoration, our work goes far beyond function ‚Äî we design statement pieces that transform a space. We‚Äôre not just reupholstering furniture; we‚Äôre creating one-of-a-kind pieces that reflect the client‚Äôs vision, style and story.

Tell us about your biggest success so far.¬†

Seeing my work featured in homes I never imagined I‚Äôd have the opportunity to be part of. Over the past year, I‚Äôve had the honor of creating custom pieces for private clients whose taste and stature I deeply admire ‚Äî individuals I never expected to connect with, let alone have my artwork in their personal spaces.

What is your top challenge and how have you addressed it?

Like many creatives-turned-entrepreneurs, I quickly learned that talent alone isn‚Äôt enough to build a business. One of my first challenges was navigating the startup phase ‚Äî figuring out pricing, sourcing materials and positioning myself in a niche market. I had to learn how to run a business while still being the creative force behind every piece, which meant wearing many hats and making decisions that didn‚Äôt always come naturally at first.

As the business began to grow, scaling up became the next big hurdle. I found myself reaching capacity quickly, with more requests than I could handle solo. It forced me to evaluate how I could grow without compromising the quality or uniqueness of my work. I‚Äôve since streamlined my process, established stronger boundaries around production timelines, and begun forming partnerships that allow me to take on more without losing the personal touch.

Have you experienced any significant personal situations that affected your business decisions?¬†

As we began to gain traction, I was thrilled to see demand increase. I hired staff, took on large-scale projects, and worked with designers on high-volume orders. On the surface, it looked like success ‚Äî but in reality, I found myself drifting further and further from the soul of what I had created.

Many of the pieces I was producing no longer felt like mine. I was executing someone else‚Äôs vision, with little input or creative freedom, simply because they had seen my past work and wanted me to replicate it. It became clear that I was on the verge of turning my studio into a production line, and that was never what I wanted this business to be. So, I made the conscious decision to recalibrate ‚Äî to scale with intention, not volume.

What is your biggest tip for other startup entrepreneurs?¬†

Trust your instinct and protect your craft. In the early stages, it‚Äôs easy to feel pulled in every direction by trends, advice or what you think people want from you. But your vision is the core of your business ‚Äì it‚Äôs what will set you apart.

How do you find inspiration on your darkest days?

I‚Äôve learned to take a step back and reconnect with my ‚Äúwhy.‚Äù I reflect on the pieces I‚Äôm most proud of, the clients who trusted me with their vision, and the moments that reminded me that I‚Äôm doing what I love.

title: Before Trump‚Äôs Efforts to Make Kids Healthier, There Was Michelle Obama
excerpt: Flickr )
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Flickr)

This story was originally reported by Barbara Rodriguez of The 19th. Meet Barbara and read more of their reporting on gender, politics and policy.

At an elementary school in Washington, D.C., the speaker at the podium wanted to talk about children‚Äôs health and the impact of childhood obesity.

‚ÄúOur generation is facing so many devastating health problems because of how we live and how we eat ‚Äî illnesses like diabetes and heart disease and cancer ‚Äî that cause so much suffering and cost our economy billions,‚Äù the speaker said. ‚ÄúAnd today, we need to ask ourselves: Are we going to hand down these problems to our next generation? Or are we going to do what we‚Äôve always done in this country and leave something better for our children and our grandchildren?‚Äù

Someone could mistake these words as being spoken in 2025 by a Trump administration official advocating to ‚ÄúMake America Healthy Again‚Äù ‚Äî the catch-all agenda that has zeroed in on kids‚Äô health and in particular, chronic disease and childhood obesity.

But the remarks were from then-first lady Michelle Obama, and the year was 2013.

Obama was promoting ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Move!,‚Äù her initiative aimed at improving children‚Äôs nutrition at home and school and encouraging them to exercise more. The initiative is credited with making improvements to school lunch standards, creating more transparency in food labeling and bringing more awareness to childhood obesity.

But the first lady drew widespread partisan backlash for her efforts, as right-wing media personalities and Republicans vehemently criticized related regulation as government overreach. They have been more muted as the Trump administration, led in part by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., now adopts similar messaging about children‚Äôs health.

‚ÄúI do think that there‚Äôs a double standard going on, especially with RFK Jr.,‚Äù said Sydney Carr-Glenn, a political science professor at the College of the Holy Cross in Massachusetts who studies the intersectionality of race and gender for Black women in politics, including in the media. ‚ÄúPeople seem to be a little bit more accepting or a little bit more on board with this whole ‚ÄòMake America Healthy Again‚Äô initiative.‚Äù

Last month, President Donald Trump announced he would revive the presidential fitness test, a once ubiquitous staple of school gym class. Just a few years ago, Let‚Äôs Move! offered programming to educators to encourage physical activity at school for at least 60 minutes each day.

In some ways, Michelle Obama‚Äôs health policy efforts walked so MAHA could run. But you won‚Äôt find many Republicans acknowledging that.

‚ÄúWe live in such polarized times now that you would think the Trump administration would look at the things that Michelle Obama achieved and maybe try to build upon that,‚Äù said Sharon Wright Austin, a political science professor at the University of Florida. ‚ÄúBut there is no collaboration. There are no coalitions. I‚Äôm sure if you were to say to Trump, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre doing the same thing that Michelle Obama originally started doing when Barack Obama was president,‚Äô he would probably not only deny it, but he probably would be pretty offended.‚Äù

Obama‚Äôs motivation to launch Let‚Äôs Move!, the first lady explained, was rooted in her experience as a working mother trying to feed her kids nutritious food. The self-described ‚Äúmom-in-chief‚Äù recognized that if she struggled with what to feed her children, other families with fewer resources might, too.

Within months of moving into the White House, the first lady started a vegetable garden to help teach children about locally grown food and to start a conversation about their health. She launched ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Move‚Äù in early 2010, and her husband issued a directive to establish a task force on childhood obesity. Michelle Obama was present months later when the task force released a report assessing how to reduce childhood obesity within a generation. It included roughly 70 voluntary recommendations.

She‚Äôll Plan a Good Time ‚Äì For a Good Cause

Almost 20 years ago, Melva LaJoy Legrand launched her first events company, LaJoy Event Design. The Washington, D.C.-based entrepreneur spent years planning parties and more for mission-driven organizations, coordinating upwards of 20 events per year at her busiest. But when Covid first began to spread in 2020, Legrand‚Äôs company took a huge hit. Despite losing 98% of her business, she remained undeterred, and worked to build the firm back up. And that she did, doubling her yearly revenue each year for the past 3 years and expanding to produce events in 42 states. Legrand, who recently rebranded her business as LaJoy Creative, takes pride in her ability to shift, adapt and pivot as needed ‚Äì telling us that doing so has helped her become a more resilient leader.¬†

Here‚Äôs our lightly edited Q&A, from The Story Exchange 1,000+ Stories Project.

Tell us about your biggest success so far.¬†

Using my expertise to contribute to conversations around the gender pay gap and blending profit with purpose. Winning coveted awards such as the 2025 Inc. Female Founders 500, SUCCESS Magazine‚Äôs Women of Influence 2024, and landing speaking opportunities with IMEX America, IMEX Frankfurt, and four cities of the BizBash Connect Conference.¬†

What is your top challenge and how have you addressed it?

Whether it‚Äôs facing a global pandemic, navigating staff changes, or the loss of clients, I always embrace the pivot. I try to lead with empathy, and find joy in my personal and professional life.

Have you experienced any significant personal situations that affected your business decisions?¬†

The pandemic was a huge challenge for us. At the time, I was also the caretaker for my ailing father, Melvin, who passed in 2021. And, I have had to deal with my own health conditions in recent years. But I‚Äôve always found a way to come out on the other side.

What is your biggest tip for other startup entrepreneurs?¬†

I actually started a YouTube leadership series, ‚ÄúMondays with Melva,‚Äù to share some of the lessons I‚Äôve learned while running my own business. I‚Äôm hopeful that this series will help other entrepreneurs navigate imposter syndrome, ensure their work is done with heart and empathy, and learn to understand the difference between ‚ÄúFOMO‚Äù (fear of missing out) and leadership rest.¬†

How do you find inspiration on your darkest days?

My love for my late father, Melvin, is the driving force behind getting through my darkest days. The love he gave me allows me to remain committed to my mission and gives me the confidence to know I can do anything.

What is your go-to song to get motivated on tough days?

‚ÄúUnstoppable‚Äù by Koryn Hawthrone.

Who is your most important role model?

I have two. Shirley Chisholm, the first Black woman to be elected to congress in 1968, and my mother, Joyce Jones. They have both shaped the way I embrace and navigate life as a dark-skinned Black woman. ‚óæ

title: Should dating apps have HIV filters?
excerpt: Grindr came under fire because of a user survey about an HIV filter
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Story highlights

Grindr came under fire because of a user survey about an HIV filter

Experts said a filter for HIV status would most likely do more harm than good

After uploading those carefully selected profile photos and writing a well-crafted personal bio for a dating app, you‚Äôre now thinking, ‚ÄúWhat type of person am I actually looking for?‚Äù

Dating apps and sites offer the option to filter matches by sex, ethnicity, height or religion ‚Äì but they could be even more personal.

This summer, the gay social networking app Grindr caught some criticism for asking in a user survey ‚ÄúWhat is your current HIV status?‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow would you feel if Grindr allowed you to filter the guys you see by HIV status?‚Äù

In a statement, a Grindr representative said the survey is an effort to better understand its users and to encourage discussions.

‚ÄúWe have observed a significant increase in user profiles openly discussing their HIV status and test dates. Given that this has not been a part of our profile options to date, we are surveying users to determine both their desire to share this information, and ways to prevent stigma and provide proper support,‚Äù the statement said. ‚ÄúSometimes this involves asking uncomfortable questions.‚Äù

Screenshots of the survey were posted online by Daniel Reeders, a Ph.D. candidate who studies HIV stigma at Australian National University. He got the images from a colleague, he said, and called the filter a ‚Äúdigital quarantine.‚Äù

‚ÄúDating sites and apps shouldn‚Äôt ask for HIV status, because there‚Äôs no way to guarantee that privacy and safety will be protected for people who disclose they are positive,‚Äù Reeders said. ‚ÄúThe harassment that ‚Äòpoz‚Äô (HIV-positive) people face can be extreme, even though it‚Äôs from a small segment of the community. People already have the ability to disclose their status in their profile text, if they choose to do so.‚Äù

Indeed, public health and relationship experts suggest that HIV or other STD filters on a dating app might do more harm than good.

More harm than good?

Although an HIV filter could have the benefit of letting HIV-positive people meet others ‚Äì avoiding potentially awkward and stigmatizing conversations ‚Äì it also could have a dark side: creating a false sense of security, said Dr. Eric Schrimshaw, associate professor of sociomedical sciences at Columbia University.

Some states have laws that mandate the disclosure of HIV status prior to any kind of sexual activity. But for some, a dating app filter could lead HIV-negative people to think that the filtered matches consist of only HIV-negative people, he said. From there, they might engage in unprotected sex.

This could lead to HIV infections because ‚Äúone, the potential partner might not be telling the truth in order to be able to get partners or to avoid stigma, and also the person may simply have engaged in behaviors recently that result in status change that they just don‚Äôt know yet.‚Äù

Another concern is that such filters could increase stigma and discrimination against people living with HIV by further isolating them socially and ‚Äúdemonizing the population.‚Äù

‚ÄúWith more HIV stigma and discrimination, you are going to have less people who will get tested,‚Äù said Dr. Gary Harper, a public health professor at the University of Michigan

Since most STDs are temporary and treatable, such as gonorrhea and chlamydia, people are more likely to seek treatment as soon as possible, Harper said; they wouldn‚Äôt even think to include them in their dating profiles. But a filter for any incurable STD, like herpes, could increase stigma, experts said.

Harper added that imposing a filter on dating app users takes away privacy rights: You may no longer have control over who can disclose information about your HIV status on an online network of strangers.

Dating apps and the rise of STDs

Online dating sites and mobile dating applications where users can create profiles and meet with strangers, have become increasingly popular among Americans. According to the Pew Research Center, about 15% of adults in the United States are now using online or mobile matchmaking services to seek potential partners, a 36% increase from 2013.

title: How Grindr got men to self-test for HIV
excerpt: The app Grindr is an effective way to distribute HIV self-test kits, a study shows
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Story highlights

The app Grindr is an effective way to distribute HIV self-test kits, a study shows

Researchers think making HIV testing available through mobile tech can prevent virus' spread

Grindr, a dating app for gay men, was found to be an effective way to give out HIV self-test kits to men at risk of infection and reduce the spread of HIV, according to a recent study.

The study targeted black and Hispanic Grindr users in Los Angeles, a high-risk population that is often untested for HIV.

Gay-related and HIV-related stigma and lack of access to health care often keep these men from getting tested, according to Dr. A. Lina Rosengren, lead author of the study and an infectious diseases fellow at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. The study says that not only are the home test kits convenient, they can help bypass some of those stigmas by providing anonymity.

With a swab of the gums, the oral fluid test kits distributed in the study deliver results in 20 minutes. If the results are positive, participants are advised to seek additional blood tests for confirmation.

Researchers offered free access to these HIV home test kits through banner ads and full-screen notifications on Grindr. Clicking on the ads took users to the study‚Äôs website, where they could choose how they want to receive the test kit: by mail, using a redeemable voucher at a local pharmacy or with a code for use at a vending machine. They were also invited to complete two surveys, an online survey at the time of the test request and a follow-up after getting tested.

The researchers chose Grindr because of its popularity among gay men in Los Angeles. The app attracts 2 million daily active users in 192 countries, according to its website.

The study‚Äôs website received 4,389 unique visits over four weeks and 333 test kit requests.

Among the 125 participants who answered the first survey, 74% reported having unprotected anal sex at least once in the past three months. Twenty-nine percent were last tested for HIV more than a year ago, and 9% had never been tested for HIV.

Of the 56 users who took the follow-up survey, two tested positive for HIV. Still, 77% of those users preferred testing at home to doing so in clinical settings.

The pilot study, spearheaded by the University of California, Los Angeles, is part of a larger effort to incorporate HIV self-testing with mobile technology.

Join the conversation

‚ÄúWe were surprised about the number of people who were willing to engage with us in health prevention through mobile apps,‚Äù Rosengren said. ‚ÄúPeople are comfortable receiving and giving fairly private health information through mobile technology.‚Äù

She hopes the study can inspire future efforts in HIV prevention and more research that finds ways to bridge the gap between HIV testing and early, proper treatment.

The FDA has approved two types of home HIV tests, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Home Access HIV-1 Test System involves pricking your finger and sending the blood sample to a licensed laboratory, with results available seven business days after shipment. The other one is the oral fluid testing type used in the study. Both tests are anonymous.

title: When sex is bad for men, good for women
excerpt: Having great sex often doubled older man's risk of heart problems, study says
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Story highlights

Having great sex often doubled older man's risk of heart problems, study says

But frequent, pleasurable sex for older women protected their hearts, it says

If you‚Äôre an older man in a relationship and you have sex once a week or more, you may be twice as likely to have a heart attack, stroke or other cardiovascular event than a less sexually active man, according to a study released this week in the Journal of Health and Social Behavior. Especially if you enjoy it.

‚ÄúOlder men who found sex with their partner extremely pleasurable, or satisfying, had higher risk of cardiovascular events than men who did not feel so,‚Äù said study author Hui Liu, associate professor of sociology at Michigan State University.

The study analyzed survey data from 2,204 people enrolled in the National Social Life, Health and Aging Project in the United States. Men and women aged 57 to 85 in partnered relationships were asked about their sexual satisfaction, frequency and health status in 2005, then again five years later. Each person‚Äôs cardiovascular health was also recorded by measuring their blood pressure, heart rate, elevated C-reactive protein and history of heart attacks, heart failure and strokes.

While the analysis found great sex is risky for men in the survey, those who had sex one to three times a month and rated it less pleasurable had no increased risk for heart concerns.

For their female partners, however, results were different. Women who said they had frequent, extremely satisfying sex had a lower risk of hypertension, a common precursor to heart disease.

Mediocre sex better for heart health?

‚ÄúThese findings challenge the widely held assumption that sex brings uniform health benefits to everyone,‚Äù Liu said. ‚ÄúI think it is important for older people to understand the potential risks and benefits of sex.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have to interpret this data with grain of salt,‚Äù said Dr. Kevin Campbell, a cardiologist at the University of North Carolina who specializes in heart rhythm disorders. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in direct contrast with the significant clinical data we have showing that as men age if they continue to be sexually active their risk of cardiovascular disease actually decreases.

‚ÄúI tell my patients a month after they have a heart attack or open heart surgery if they can walk a flight of steps without getting chest pain or shortness of breath,‚Äù said Campbell, ‚Äúthen they are fine to resume sexual activity.‚Äù

Surprising results for men

‚ÄúThe results for men were surprising,‚Äù said Lui, agreeing they run counter to decades of research that shows a positive health effect from sexual behavior for men, including better prostate health.

One reason for the unusual findings, she said, could be in the design of the study. She said while other research has tended to focus on younger age groups, this survey was on a nationally representative sample of older adults across the United States.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a survey, not a gold-standard, randomized, clinically controlled trial,‚Äù countered Campbell, also highlighting that the study was conducted in 2005, with a follow-up in 2010. ‚ÄúIs it really relevant now that most everyone is on a statin and our treatment of cardiovascular disease has continued to improve?‚Äù he asked.

Another reason for her findings, Lui said, might lie in the use of erectile dysfunction supplements by many older men, or the level of stress created by the act of sex itself.

‚ÄúOlder men may have more difficulties reaching an orgasm for medical or emotional reasons,‚Äù Lui said. ‚ÄúTherefore, they may exert themselves to a greater degree of exhaustion and create relatively more stress on their cardiovascular system in order to achieve a climax, which may hurt health.‚Äù

That could possibly be true, Campbell said, if the man is suffering from an unknown cardiovascular blockage or if he is using certain medications for existing heart disease.

‚ÄúIf they are taking any type of nitroglycerin, it can cause a dramatic drop in blood pressure with any of the erectile dysfunction drugs,‚Äù Campbell said. ‚ÄúThat needs to be monitored very carefully.‚Äù

title: The Environmental Justice Movement Isn‚Äôt Going Anywhere ‚Äî Even As It Faces Attacks by Trump
excerpt: University of Michigan )
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
University of Michigan)

This story was originally reported by Jessica Kutz of The 19th. Meet Jessica and read more of her reporting on gender, politics and policy.

Under the Biden administration, the environmental justice movement had a historic platform to bring clean water and air to communities that have suffered from pollution. It was a boon to the grassroots movement, which started in the 1980s in response to a pattern of permitting landfills and polluting industries in neighborhoods that were disproportionately Black, Brown and low-income.

In the past four years, advisory councils were created ‚Äî with many of the positions filled by women of color, who have long been leaders in environmental justice spaces ‚Äî and offices opened to spearhead the work on the federal level. During that time, the administration also earmarked billions of dollars to address longstanding environmental issues, and to help these communities adapt to the climate crisis.

But as President Donald Trump took office for a second time, all that momentum at the federal level disappeared, seemingly overnight. An executive order issued on inauguration day took aim at dismantling diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives, and environmental justice. As a result, any mention of the work is being scrubbed from government websites and funding has been paused.

For Jalonne White-Newsome, who led the first ever office on environmental justice in the White House, the shift has been jarring if not unexpected. Still, she‚Äôs not undaunted. Through her over three decades of working in environmental justice ‚Äî starting from her youth in Detroit, Michigan ‚Äî there is one thing she knows: The movement, at its core, is driven by everyday people who will continue to advocate for their communities.

‚ÄúEnvironmental justice did not start with the federal government,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúNor will it end with the federal government.‚Äù

The 19th spoke with White-Newsome, formerly the federal environmental justice officer for the White House Council on Environmental Quality, about the Trump administration‚Äôs recent attacks on her work and how the movement responds now.

This interview has been edited for length and clarity.¬†

Jessica Kutz: What is it like to see the new administration issue executive orders aimed at dismantling environmental justice, work that you played a part in implementing?

Jalonne White-Newsome: I mean, it‚Äôs crushing, right? It is offensive. It‚Äôs really hard because we have really tried to work hard over these past four years to create a foundation that our federal family could build on.To see a lot of that dismantled, to see our information wiped off websites, to really try and eliminate the trace of any environmental justice work, it‚Äôs very frustrating.

How do you think this pull back in funding will affect the momentum of the movement? Is there work that was done under Biden that might be protected from this shift?¬†

I‚Äôve had so many community leaders over the past couple years come up to me, folks that have been in the movement for decades and decades, to say there has never been this amount of funding and resources to support environmental justice.

And so our agency partners worked really, really hard to try and get as much money out as possible [before the Trump administration]. I mean, they were grinding very hard.

I know there are groups that are positioning to make sure that communities can keep the funds that were obligated to them. So that is happening right now. Where it gets sticky is some of the funds were kind of in that period of not being obligated. [Especially with] the current administration‚Äôs review of anything that remotely thinks, talks or looks like equity or environmental justice.

I‚Äôm not a lawyer. Is that legal? Can they actually do that? I don‚Äôt know. But it‚Äôs a fear tactic, right? And they‚Äôre trying to cause fear and confusion, and they have been successful. But we have great partners that have a lot of knowledge and passion that are going to protect our folks that have received these funds to continue to do the great work that they‚Äôre doing on the ground.

What are your concerns about this political shift away from DEI and environmental justice work?¬†

title: Know a Trailblazing Woman Scientist? Nominate Her for Our ‚ÄòCutting-Edge Women in Science‚Äô List
excerpt: The Story Exchange , an award-winning nonprofit media platform dedicated to elevating women‚Äôs voices, is seeking nominations for its Cutting-Edge Women in Science list.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The Story Exchange, an award-winning nonprofit media platform dedicated to elevating women‚Äôs voices, is seeking nominations for its Cutting-Edge Women in Science list.¬†

The list will spotlight U.S.-based women with a deep background in science whose work is driven by the dangerous realities of the climate crisis. We are specifically looking for women who are motivated to find urgent, innovative, science-based solutions as global warming impacts the safety of our water, air and soil; disrupts food systems and communities; and poses significant threats to biodiversity and ecosystems.¬†

‚ÄúWe particularly encourage nominations of early- and mid-career female scientists, whose work might benefit the most from this recognition,‚Äù said Sue Williams, executive director of The Story Exchange. ‚ÄúOur mission is to support and highlight these remarkable professionals, at a time when women ‚Äì and especially women in STEM fields ‚Äì still face barriers to advancement.‚Äù

The focus on women also comes as more research indicates that women are disproportionately impacted by climate change. An Association of American Medical Colleges analysis in 2024 found that women around the world are more likely to experience injury and death as a result of catastrophic weather events, often in the form of pregnancy complications and sexual violence. UN Climate Change earlier this year called for more integration of gender into climate policy and action.¬†

The 2025 Cutting-Edge Women in Science list will be chosen based on nominations from members of the scientific community and an assessment by The Story Exchange editors. Final picks will be recognized this fall on our site, shared with media partners, and potentially featured in video and podcasts. As an example, please see our video (below) and podcast on Kerry Kelly, a University of Utah professor of chemical engineering who is an expert on air quality and the founder of Tellus, a maker of air quality sensors.

To nominate a candidate, please head to our form. Please note: You cannot nominate yourself.¬†

Candidates must be U.S.-based scientists with advanced degrees in the fields of physics, chemistry, engineering, biology, agronomy, environmental science, meteorology or closely related fields; or entrepreneurs with advanced degrees who are creating science-based products and technologies to help mitigate/reduce the impact of climate change through innovative practices.

‚ÄúFor many years, we have highlighted the incredible accomplishments of women in science, who are often racing against the clock to adapt our world to the dangers of climate change,‚Äù said Victoria Wang, co-founder of The Story Exchange. ‚ÄúAt a time when there is little reason to be optimistic about the environment, these women stand out as beacons of hope.‚Äù ‚óºÔ∏è

title: Never Again Crazy Like Wei Hui
excerpt: Zhang Yueran is the author of five novels and three short story collections. Her upcoming novel, Women, Seated , will be published in English in 2025 by Riverhead Books.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Zhang Yueran is the author of five novels and three short story collections. Her upcoming novel, Women, Seated, will be published in English in 2025 by Riverhead Books.

Wei Hui is the author of Shanghai Baby. Published in 1999, the novel was banned in China.

Earlier this year, they discussed censorship, tradition and women‚Äôs autobiographical writing in China.

¬†

Zhang Yueran

I met Wei Hui one afternoon in January at YongFoo √âlite, a restaurant on Shanghai‚Äôs Yongfu Road. The old Western-style structure, once home to the British Consulate, cut a forlorn figure in the winter. The listless green of the parasol trees in the courtyard did little to keep at bay the cold seeping between the stone paving slabs. We were some of the few customers there. Wei Hui had chosen the location. ‚ÄòI had a lot of fun here in my youth,‚Äô she explained. The idea of ‚Äòfun‚Äô, in this context, is not all that meaningful beyond simply killing time. While away a couple hours with someone and you could say you ‚Äòhad fun with them‚Äô. I have the impression the phrase came into use around the time Wei Hui was still writing, and that it represents an attitude, a bold declaration that adults ought to have fun, too. I was one of Wei Hui‚Äôs readers then. As a frustrated middle-school student, I often turned to her books during evening study periods. Her novels were a sort of promise: when I grew up, I would also be someone who had fun, like she did ‚Äì unlike my parents.

I‚Äôm a big fan of your novel Crazy Like Wei Hui, I told her. ‚ÄòYes? I think I did a good job with that one, too,‚Äô Wei Hui replied, grinning. She talked about her past self as if recalling an old friend, with admiration and tenderness, though her tone was tinged with loss. There is a clear rupture in her person ‚Äì as if without breaking from her past, she would be incapable of fully occupying who she is now. It was the year 2000 when Shanghai Baby was banned and she left China for the United States. ‚ÄòWhen 9/11 happened, I was eating breakfast,‚Äô she said in one interview. The image she paints is that she watched through her window as the airplanes crashed into the Twin Towers, the implication being that 9/11 was the very thing that shattered her American Dream. But the reality is that she was unable to integrate into America. In her own words, she was not as Westernised as she had imagined. Returning to China, she married hurriedly and had a child. Her marriage quickly fell apart, and during that difficult period, she came across psychotherapy and became a psychotherapist herself. She also developed a rich interest in traditional Chinese culture. Throughout our conversation, she expressed her views in the languages of both. It didn‚Äôt matter how far afield I pitched my questions, she always managed to wend her way back to these territories. Getting Zhou Weihui, the woman across the table from me, to discuss Wei Hui, the woman she used to be, was not going to be simple. It‚Äôs worth noting the change in name: having forsaken her surname when she decided to become a writer, she has since readopted the patronymic, which may in part have been a response to the desire to reconnect with her lineage.

Although the conversation with Wei Hui was not always straightforward. On some level, the rupture, and rejection, and her highly-stylised way of speaking, are linked to her early literary career and how that career ended. Beneath her outward composure lies a lasting confusion, which I glimpsed when she asked: Why was Jia Pingwa not banned, when I was?

title: Summer Reads 2025
excerpt: Granta contributors, friends and staff share what they are reading this summer.
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
Granta contributors, friends and staff share what they are reading this summer.

¬†

JESSE BARRON

I regret the day that my friend Jessica said she was reading The Years of Lyndon Johnson.‚ÄØShe made it sound easy. Ever since then, I‚Äôve been trapped in this four-volume work by Robert Caro, and in the musty world of mid-century American politics. Three volumes in, I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm enjoying it anymore, yet I seem unable to stop, propelled by the same joyless doggedness with which Johnson himself pursued power. One of the many things that drives me crazy about Caro is that he loads‚ÄØhis prose with excess freight: a former governor of Texas ‚Äòwas not only not typical but was, in fact, unique.‚Äô‚ÄØA simple ‚Äòand‚Äô will never do; Caro must add ‚Äòmoreover‚Äô. I would throw the book across the room, but it‚Äôs too heavy to lift ‚Äì and, moreover, the pleasures outweigh the frustrations. The most beautiful parts of Caro are the historical reconstructions, the set pieces that plunge you into the Texas Hill Country of the 1920s or the Senate cloakroom of 1949. And there‚Äôs the tender ‚Äì the trampled ‚Äì figure of Lady Bird. Johnson courted her with chivalry and charm, used her father‚Äôs money to‚ÄØenter politics, then treated her like a servant and humiliated her in public for the rest of their marriage. Lady Bird never says a mean word back.‚ÄØShe speaks for the whole Vietnam generation when she tells Caro, of her home life with Johnson, ‚ÄòLyndon‚Äôs wishes dominate.‚Äô

¬†

TOM BOLGER

These past three weeks I‚Äôve read three slim books. Although I caught some teasing flak for The Bloody Chamber by Angela Carter (‚ÄòAre you doing your A-levels?‚Äô), it is hard not to be intoxicated by the violent and sensual collection, not so much a subversion of fairy tales and the Gothic, but a fine distillation of their dormant desires and fears ‚Äì the tossed-sheets-tussle of Eros and Thanatos. I‚Äôve also arrived late to the Janet Malcolm party, first reading The Journalist and the Murderer, then The Silent Woman. The former investigates with cool precision the implicitly comprised journalist‚Äìsubject relationship, and the inadequacy of language and memory when gesturing towards ‚Äòthe truth‚Äô. Her attention to detail, her ability to swiftly capture someone‚Äôs presence, their contradictions, is exceptional. The latter ‚Äì a submersion into the divergent biographies of Sylvia Plath ‚Äì continues to haunt me; who owns our work, our incomprehensible life, in death? It is devastating and eviscerating, yet often sympathetic to its central players. I plan to work my way through Malcolm‚Äôs archive in the coming months.

¬†

ANNE CARSON

accidentally i am reading collections of stories by people named Elizabeth
Bowen
Hardwick
Taylor
they are all terrific.

¬†

ALEXANDER CLAPP

I‚Äôve spent most of the last year in Southeast Colombia working on a new book project. My companions have been some of the classics of Amazonian anthropology: Michael Taussig‚Äôs Shamanism, Colonialism, and the Wild Man¬†and Gerardo Reichel-Dolmatoff‚Äôs famous study of Tukano mythology, Amazonian Cosmos. Both are waterlogged. My last copy of Tristes Tropiques disintegrated in a rainstorm somewhere on the Rio Caqueta.‚ÄØFor pleasure I‚Äôve been reading Vargas Llosa novels ‚Äì The Storyteller, The Dream of the Celt ‚Äì and Norman Lewis‚Äôs newly-collected essays, A Quiet Evening. Sometimes, before longer trips, I‚Äôll print out NLR ‚ÄØor LRB pieces‚ÄØfor the canoe or Jeep. I have a habit of leaving them behind in the lobbies of shabby hotels. I smile at the idea of strangers, months later, chancing upon a Perry Anderson or Neal Ascherson essay deep in the wilderness of the Amazon.

¬†

JOSHUA COHEN

title: Badlands
excerpt: The badlands of this issue refer to inhospitable terrain, whether on land or in the mind. Eighty years after the end of the Second World War, multiple times the firepower inflicted on Hiroshima has been dropped on Gaza in savage pursuit of Palestinian oblivion, while the Houth‚Ä¶
author: AventurOO Editorial
body:
The badlands of this issue refer to inhospitable terrain, whether on land or in the mind. Eighty years after the end of the Second World War, multiple times the firepower inflicted on Hiroshima has been dropped on Gaza in savage pursuit of Palestinian oblivion, while the Houthi dissenters in Yemen continue to break world records: first combat exchange in outer space, highest number of US drones destroyed, first non-state actor to down an F-18. In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the mineral-rich eastern region of Kivu, an area the size of Western Europe, has been a geopolitical badlands for three decades. In Sudan, a deadlocked civil war fractures the country anew. These are only some of the areas on Earth whose uninhabitability is accelerating.

And Europe? A proxy war still rages there between Russia and the United States, with the Ukrainian people paying the price. What is remarkable is how much of the devastation has been confined within the national borders of pre-2014 Ukraine. Bombings and assassinations in Moscow are, at the time of writing, still rare, and the counter-invasion of Kursk by three Ukrainian brigades has come to naught. Mystifyingly, in the sleepy town of Wiesbaden, Germany ‚Äì the de facto headquarters of the Western alliance, where NATO officials and Ukrainian commanders coordinate targets ‚Äì the Russians have not raised a finger. In Berlin in 2022, I remember seeing the dead tropical fish on Karl-Liebknecht-Stra√üe in the aftermath of the explosion of the AquaDom, widely speculated to have been the result of a Russian attack at the time, and thinking: this is what the war will be like when Moscow starts coloring harder outside the lines. But both the US and Russia have an interest in keeping the conflict confined to Ukraine. For the US, the ongoing war underlines the terms of European dependence on American arms and energy. For Russia, it has helped put the economy on a new, more autonomous footing. If the oft-dangled peace arrives, it will be the result of sated appetites as much as exhaustion. At some point Russia will want to consolidate its gains, while the US wants to keep open capacities that may be needed in the Middle East and East Asia.

For this issue,¬†Granta¬†sent William T. Vollmann into the drone-infested Ukrainian badlands. Vollmann describes himself as a writer low on fitness but high on endurance. In 1982, when he was twenty-two, he joined the Afghan mujahideen fighting against the Soviet invasion (a portion of his account appeared in Granta 40). Vollmann has staged collisions of his innocence with rough country ever since: Sarajevo, Fukushima, the Korean DMZ. ‚ÄòI went to help [Ukraine] in my helpless way, with journalistic good intentions which sorrowed into love,‚Äô he writes. The good intentions would verge on naive if Vollmann did not hitch them to sober-eyed appraisals of his surroundings. There are few writers of contemporary reportage who see as many shades of color beyond the windshield. In Ukraine, Vollmann finds distraught mourners, hardened dog-lovers, defensive literary critics, and wised-up drone pilots. His chief interlocutors, however, are the two modernist giants of the region: Joseph Roth and Isaac Babel. In his affectionate way, Vollmann confronts a puritanism among some Ukrainians he meets that recalls Soviet history-scrubbing excesses: the pressure to purge vestiges of a shared past, in an effort to decontaminate Ukraine from the taint of Russian culture. While trying to summon reasons for leaving a statue of Babel intact, Vollmann asks: ‚ÄòIsn‚Äôt genius enough?‚Äô

Vollmann once supplied a dark clue for the origins of his strenuous attention to detail. In 1968, when he was nine years old, he was told to watch over his sister at a pond in New Hampshire. The pond had a steep drop-off and his sister drowned. ‚ÄòI just stopped paying attention at one point,‚Äô Vollmann recalled. ‚ÄòI was lost in some sort of daydream.‚Äô For a decade afterward, he describes having ‚Äònightmares practically every night ‚Äì of her skeleton chasing me and punishing me‚Äô. Part of the way out of being pursued for Vollmann has been to become a great noticer of everything around him.
